{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-year-in-arts-entertainment-and-culture/article_d2c52c02-d2d1-579b-a8cb-d180dac0a433.html", "TITLE": " The Year in Arts, Entertainment and Culture ", "DATE": "Jan 1, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "accused: Science and Technology Minister Dr Rupert Griffith leaves the Port of Spain Magistrates' Court yesterday. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY hot, hot, hot: Calypsonian Arrow passed away. accused: Science and Technology Minister Dr Rupert Griffith leaves the Port of Spain Magistrates' Court yesterday. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY hot, hot, hot: Calypsonian Arrow passed away. DJ's do damage The nation palanced into 2010 and continued to frolic to the phenomenal hit song well past Ash Wednesday when radio personalities cum soca artistes, JW and Blaze were declared the year's Road March winners. Racking up a play count of an amazing 417 times on the road Carnival Monday and Tuesday, \"Palance\" beat defending Road March queen, Fay-Ann Lyons whose \"True Lies\" came in second with just 40 plays. Machel Montano took third place with his \"No Behaviour,\" which garnered only 11 plays. JW and Blaze convincingly also won the International Soca Monarch title on Carnival Friday becoming the first duo act to do so. In the way of airplay \"Palance\" enjoyed a platform other Road March winners did not as the song received heavy rotation on at least ten radio stations, free to air and cable television as well as over the internet on sites such as YouTube, Facebook, Toronto Lime and others. Of course there was some controversy over \"Palance\" as some soca artistes complained that with JW and Blaze being radio and television personalities the field of play was set in their favour as their song and accompanying video would receive as much airplay as they wished. Some artistes expressed the opinion that radio DJs and television VJs had no right singing soca. JW, Blaze and other radio and television personalities such as Shal Marshall, Supa Jigga TC and Akil \"5-Star\" Borneo who also perform soca and other forms of music defended themselves saying that it is everyone's right to be a performing artiste if they so desire. \"There is no degree or special training required to sing soca. If a person, whoever that may be, desires to sing soca there is nothing that can stop them,\" JW said when questioned about people's objections to him and Blaze performing. The Birdie still flying In July 2010 news of the passing of the Mighty Sparrow rocked the world with people frantically sending emails, Facebook messages, texting and calling to find out whether the news was true. It all began when, during a show at NAPA titled Celebrating Our Calypso Monarchs 1939-1980 - T&T's History Through the Eyes of Calypso, Sparrow had to be assisted onto the stage and performed seated. Midway through his presentation it seemed that Sparrow was in pain and ended his performance. The speculation began with people saying Sparrow was experiencing complications due to diabetes and that he was having heart problems. A couple weeks later while performing in Washington DC, Sparrow again had to stop in the midst of his performance. After being examined by doctors at the event, he was taken to hospital where he underwent surgery to treat an incarcerated right inguinal hernia. The Calypso King of the World has been doing well since although on the day fellow calypsonian Arrow died, a radio station got it wrong and announced that Sparrow had passed away, again sending fans around the world into a frenzy. Over the years rumours that Sparrow had died have circulated more than once prompting him to do calypsoes, such as \"Sparrow Dead\" and \"Simpson\", tongue-in-cheek style, but at this stage of his life such rumours are no longer a joking matter. New culture at Culture The most crucial development on the local cultural front during 2010 has to be the trouncing of the PNM by the People's Partnership in May. How does this affect culture, you may be asking Well, one of the first actions taken by Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar was splitting the Ministry of Community Development, Culture and Gender Affairs into separate entities. Thus was established the Ministry of The Arts and Multiculturalism headed by Minister Winston \"Gypsy\" Peters, former national calypso monarch. A stand-alone ministry for culture had been a longstanding dream of people in the cultural fraternity and having it run by one of their peers made it all that much better. Proving to be a mover and a shaker, Peters got off to a running start with one of his first actions being the freeing up of the National Academy for the Performing Arts (NAPA). The PNM government seemed to have reserved NAPA for events hosted by then Prime Minister, Patrick Manning, UDeCott and members of Manning's administration. Also only entertainment of a certain ilk seemed suited for NAPA and previous culture minister Marlene McDonald was reported to have said the facility was not built, \"for those kinds of things\" when approached by president of the National Chutney Foundation, Vijay Ramlal to access NAPA for a chutney music event. Under the stewardship of Peters, NAPA has served as the venue for diverse events including comedy shows, calypso concerts, a children's rapso event, the hosting of a temporary museum displaying the skeleton of the T-Rex named Sue, a Divali ballet, pan events, the International Soca Awards and even a valedictorian function or two. Some people have raised the pre-election claim by the People's Parliament that there were too many flaws, requiring some $80 million in repairs, for NAPA to be of any use. They wonder how is it the facility is now suitable to be utilised for so many events of such diversity, especially since there were no visible upgrades carried out on the facility. Back to the Savannah Possibly the most exciting cultural news in 2010 was the announcement of the return of the Parade of the Bands to the Big Stage at the Queen's Park Savannah, Port of Spain, for Carnival 2011. This news was received with unanimous approval by all stakeholders of Carnival. The beloved North Stand will return to its original spot, while the temporary stand that replaced the Grand Stand will be moved opposite the North Stand and be expanded to accommodate more people. The Express was the first to break this news in August when Peters told us he had plans for an impressive structure to house Carnival at the Savannah in the long-term and temporary accommodations for the coming season. The National Carnival Commission is once again under the leadership of Kenny De Silva who previously served up to 2006. De Silva is spearheading the drive to return Carnival to the Savannah and to the people. At the time this review was being written the North Stand was already well on its way to completion. Staying with Carnival, history was made when radio personalities cum soca artistes, Jason \"JW\" Williams and Ancil \"Blaze\" Isaac released a song titled \"Palance,\" which took the nation by storm as everybody from toddler to elder and priest to politician were palancing all over the place, singing the infectious hook and doing the aerobic-styled dance. Pan palang Minister Peters commented this year that there must be bacchanal in Carnival because that adds to the magic of the festival. Well, beyond the misgivings over soca-singing DJs there was some bacchanal in the National Panorama Championship of 2010. Under the governance of new president Keith Diaz, Pan Trinbago sought to breathe new life into the Panorama, which in recent years had seen a decline in attendance possibly because of the demolition of the Grand Stand and absence of the North Stand. Diaz decided that one way to generate more revenue from Panorama would be to charge a $60 entrance fee to the area of the Savannah referred to as the Drag. This is where the steel orchestras assemble as they make their way to the stage. The pannists usually go through their paces here doing practice runs of the tune and in some cases the arrangers tweak the arrangements one final time before facing the judges. Traditionally people gather on the Drag to listen to the bands rehearse and for years had been doing so free of charge. Supporters of the respective steel orchestras, many of whom assist in pushing the pan racks onto the stage also fill the Drag. In fact the Drag had become a mini Panorama in itself and was the place to pass through on the way into the stands or the place to lime if one were not going into the Panorama staging area. Diaz's new $60 fee did not go down well with a lot of people, including some bands and their supporters. The steelbands had a problem with the fee because they felt it would affect the number of supporters accompanying them and assisting in getting them on stage. Others cried foul saying that Pan Trinbago was destroying a longstanding tradition that added to the excitement of Panorama. The Silver Stars Steel Orchestra won the 2010 National Panorama Championship retaining the title they captured for the first time ever the previous year. Playing \"Battle Zone\" composed by their arranger, Edwin Pouchet with lyrics by Alvin Daniell, the band scored 291 to beat Phase II Pan Groove, which scored 284 points, into second place. Phase II leader, Len \"Boogsie\" Sharpe was not happy and reacted angrily when the results were revealed. As November came to a close Peters incurred the wrath of the steelband fraternity when he, at an event titled Pan Relay in Laventille said, \"I believe that Panorama is responsible for killing steelpan and I make no apologies for that.\" President of Pan Trinbago, Keith Diaz was enraged and with the support of his executive and the leadership of some steel orchestras declared war on the Minister and threatened to scrap the 2011 Panorama unless he publicly apologised for his pronouncement of the most important competition for the majority of pannists. Calypso capers After some three years singing one song at the Dimanche Gras to win the National Calypso Monarch title, calypsonians voted in November to return the two-song requirement from 2011. There will still, however, be only one song required in the preliminary and semi final rounds and the finalists will then perform two calypsoes at Dimanche Gras. This decision was a compromise of sorts as some calypsonians wanted to remain with one song, while others wanted to return to two songs. With one song up to the semi-final stage everyone was happy and the decision was finalised in early December after the calypsonians from Tobago cast their votes. A source in the Trinbago Unified Calypsonians Organisation (TUCO) told the Express that Peters also expressed his desire that the two-song rule be returned. The one-song rule served Kurt Allen well as he finally, after years knocking on the door and even leaving the arena for a while, won the title in 2010 with a convincing performance of \"Too Bright\". Setting the stage with props and actors to mirror Woodford Square and dressed as a vagrant, Allen sang that although the nation has been led by politicians boasting multiple degrees and all manner of academic achievements it is still in a mess. Allen sang that the economy is on a steady decline, crime is rampant, health care in a mess along with many other problems, while so-called intellectuals squabbled over ridiculous motions in Parliament. The former international soca monarch suggested that it was time for a vagrant to be voted in as prime minister, then maybe things would take a turn for the better. After serving as TUCO president for just over a year, Eric \"Pink Panther\" Taylor decided to contest the 2010 General Elections representing the People's National Movement in the constituency of Toco/Sangre Grande but lost to Dr Rupert Griffith. Taylor did not officially resign as TUCO president and left the organisation in a state of limbo until the executive took the decision to install Lutalo \"Brother Resistance\" Masimba as president after Taylor gracefully bowed out officially. Beyonce bacchanal After Carnival was the big topic even before the season got on the way in 2010. TSTT announced it was presenting Beyonce in concert at the Queen's Park Savannah on the Thursday following Carnival. Well, the Merry Monarch and segments of the culture fraternity were up in arms and launched protest accusing TSTT of trying to destroy local culture and prevent hard working Trinidadian promoters from earning a dollar. Show promoters cried foul saying people would not attend Carnival events in order to save their money for Beyonce concert tickets of which the cost was as much as $1,600 each. TUCO joined other organisations that said the $10M production cost of the concert was too high, while promoters and other cultural event producers accused TSTT of either cutting back on or outright pulling sponsorship of local events because they were focusing finances on the Beyonce show. The Beyonce concert came off with the headline act delivering a fantastic performance in which she even sang \"Palance\" much to the delight of the thousands in attendance. Although Beyonce delivered, TSTT and its service providers could have done better as patrons complained of tripping over cables and other debris in dark holes throughout the venue. Patrons also experienced problems in the VIP washrooms and at the food stations where food seemed to run out early on the night. Other shortfalls at the show included the dust that was blowing everywhere, the poor vantage points for hundreds of patrons and the lack of security and inadequate shuttle service for patrons parked at King George V Park and other places away from the Savannah. Making movies The local film industry continues to make strides onto the international market, which was clearly evident at the 2010 Trinidad and Tobago Film Festival (TTFF) that took place from September 22 to October 5 at venues throughout both islands. The festival showcased movies, documentaries, shorts and other categories of video produced by Trinidadians and other Caribbean filmmakers. Hundreds attended showings at venues such as MovieTowne, UWI and community centres in Tobago, making this year's run of the festival the most successful to date. The success of the TTFF inspired the Indian High Commissioner, Malay Mishra to present an Indian Film Festival from November 17 to 23 at MovieTowne. The festival was in commemoration of the seventy-fifth anniversary of Indian cinema in Trinidad. Eleven films were shown at the festival, which was also a successful venture. Also taking place in 2010 was the 14th edition of the European Film Festival, which also took place at MovieTowne and featured movies, shorts and documentaries from several countries including Britain, France, Denmark, Holland, Sweden and other European territories. There was also the Animae Caribe Animation and New Media Festival in which local animators got together with their counterparts from North America, Japan, China, Mexico and the other Caribbean islands to share ideas and explore each other's work. Many people were introduced to the local animation fraternity, which has been producing material of international standards for some time now. We remember As the Mighty Sparrow sang, \"every year somebody dear gives us cause to shed a tear and mourn for they are gone.\" 2010 was no exception as the cultural and entertainment community lost several of its own. Possibly the most impacting loss was that of Arrow who, though not a Trinidadian, contributed greatly to taking the calypso and soca artforms to the world. Arrow on September 16 succumbed to pneumonia brought on by complications from the brain cancer he had been battling for about two years. Born Alphonsus Celestine Edmund Cassell on the island of Montserrat, Arrow achieved international stardom when he released \"Hot, Hot, Hot\" in 1982. The song made it on to the UK charts in 1984 and a version done by Buster Poindexter in 1987 hit the Billboard Charts in America giving the original version new life and earning Arrow millions. Around the same time Arrow passed away calypsonian and master of ceremonies at the Calypso Revue, SuperLou, died suddenly due to complications brought on by diabetes. A former fireman, SuperLou, whose birth name was Stephen Lewis was also known as the santabranga man because of the way he would refer to sex in his jokes. SuperLou had been performing at the Revue for 15 years. We also lost legendary actor, Errol Jones who passed away on June 21at the home of his niece, Marcia Riley with whom he lived for about 12 years because of a heart condition that required that he be under constant supervision. Jones was a founding member of the Trinidad Theatre Workshop, which was started by Nobel Laureate Derek Walcott in 1959. A former Immigration Officer, Jones got seriously involved in theatre when he was 26 years old and joined a group called the Whitehall Players. His first role was as a young man who was romantically involved with a priest's wife in a play titled The Indifferent Shepherd. Just as this article was heading to print we received news of the passing of Ricardo \"Smokey\" Mckenzie, owner of the world famous Smokey and Bunty's Sports Bar in St James. McKenzie had been ailing since September 2009 when he was diagnosed with a brain tumour for which he underwent surgery. This was followed by several surgeries, radiation treatment and chemotherapy. An abscess developed in his brain and McKenzie died on December 21 while receiving treatment at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. On the morning of October 22 the soca fraternity was stunned when the news hit that Blazer Dan had been killed at his home by gunmen who pumped several bullets into the artiste. His peers in the entertainment arena and others who knew him were not shocked as Blazer, real name Troydon Cruickshank, lived on the edge as it were. Blazer spent time in jail for his involvement in the death of his brother and had also been arrested for various offences. In the midst of Carnival we lost musical director and longstanding chief judge of the International Soca Monarch, Roland Gordon who suffered a stroke and slipped into a coma following a marathon run of the Soca Monarch semi-finals on January 24. Gordon had, the night before he fell ill, led the judging of over 80 artistes at the semi-finals that ran from 5.30 p.m. to after 3 a.m. the next morning. Gordon was the father of soca artiste, Roderick \"Chucky\" Gordon who was a participant in the Soca Monarch competition. President of the National Carnival Bands Association, Owen Hinds passed away on November 18 following complications from brain surgery. The veteran masmaker and trade union leader who founded the Contractors and General Workers' Trade Union took over control of the NCBA in 2005 replacing Richard Afong. New York-based calypsonian Lovey passed away suddenly on November shortly after landing in Trinidad for a visit. The cause of death was said to be an aneurism. Born Denise Moore Campbell, Lovey began her career as part of a duo alongside her cousin, Marilyn Williams. Under the name, Lovey and Dovey the two performed backing vocals in studio and on stage for just about every calypsonian who recorded during the 1970s into the 2,000s. In Concert In the way of concerts featuring regional and international acts there were even less such events than 2009, the downturn in the economy being the main reason for the decrease. The Evolution of Music concert that took place at the National Stadium on December 4 was hailed by some patrons as the best ever. We don't know about that, but the show featuring Damian \"Junior Gong\" Marley, Nas and Jah Cure was for the most part a very good production. While Marley and Nas each delivered very good performances that had the audience singing along and dancing energetically for more than two hours, Jah Cure failed to command the majority of patrons' attention when he came on after 3 a.m. People began to filter out of the venue during Jah Cure's set and by the time he was finished the Stadium was all but empty. The year's most controversial concert was the Localise ITT event that came off at the National Stadium on October 30. The event was presented by The Project Records in conjunction with the Ministry of Sport and Youth Affairs and featured Trinidad-born hip-hop artiste, Nicki Minaj who is at present the hottest female hip-hop act in the world. First there was the controversy over whether Minaj was coming to T&T or not as even after head of The Project Records, Daryl Braxton, announced that Minaj was coming there was an article on her website stating she was not. Minister of Sport and Youth Affairs, Anil Roberts, reportedly flew to New York to meet with Minaj and her management to ensure that she would perform at the event, which she eventually did. Then a couple weeks following the concert, which was featured in a special documentary on Minaj broadcast on the MTV Networks, Member of Parliament for Diego Martin Central, Dr Amery Browne called on Roberts to declare the true cost of producing the concert, which was presented using taxpayers' money. Browne also charged that Minaj used explicit lyrics before the largely youth audience, which Roberts denied. Minaj's management in turn demanded an apology from Browne, claiming he had smeared the artiste's good name. Roberts in the meantime was sent to the Privileges Committee for statements he made in defense of himself, Minaj and the Ministry. Another major event during the year was the Tobago Jazz Experience in April, which featured several top local acts alongside American artistes, Erykah Badu and Chaka Khan. The three-day event was held at the Pigeon Point Heritage Park with several small events taking place at venues across the island. One of the most memorable moments of the festival was Chaka Khan inviting Tobago's hometown heroine singer, Kay Alleyne on stage to sing \"I'm Every Woman\" alongside her. Foreign Affairs The big shocker for Trinidadians on the regional front was the arrest and subsequent indictment of Jamaican reggae artiste, Buju Banton in Florida for conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute five or more kilograms of cocaine. Although he was arrested in December 2009 the case unfolded during 2010 when in September the jury, after three days of deliberation, failed to come up with a verdict. The judge declared a mistrial, but the prosecution went before the Grand Jury to have Buju re-indicted and that case was scheduled to begin in December. Reggae music icon, Gregory Isaacs lost his battle with lung cancer when he passed away at his London home on October 25. He was 59 years old. Isaacs was best known on the international arena for his 1982 hit \"Night Nurse,\" and he was given the nickname Cool Ruler from his 1978 album of the same title. The event was launched yesterday at the COP headquarters by chairman Joseph Toney. \"The series is intended to enlighten the nation on where the country has come from since Independence and where it is going,\" Senator Patrick Watson said of the initiative. The series will run until August 31, 2012, when Trinidad and Tobago marks its 50th independence anniversary. Toney said Friday's event, which kicks off at 6 p.m., will involve a number of local entertainers, including Ravi B, Black Sage, the Shiv Shakti Dancers and the Carib Woodbrook Playboyz Steel Orchestra. COP Political Leader Winston Dookeran will also read a citation in tribute to the late former president Sir Ellis Clarke at the event. The concert will be followed by the first in the series of discussions on the topic Pioneers of Nationhood, which will be aired on television on January 31. The discussions will focus on areas of culture and the arts in February; religion in March; the Constitution, Caribbean Court of Justice, proportional representation, the right to recall and two-term limits in April; heritage in May; labour in June; and education in July. Watson said the series was not an academic exercise but documentation and recordings will be produced and made available to the national community. He said past and present leaders in several spheres have agreed to take part, share their wisdom and facilitate the discussions. DRUMMING: Women combining drumming with dance movements. For the second time in 12 months artistes from Korea have entertained and thrilled local audiences with their tradition music and dance performances. The show billed as Sounds of Korea which was held at the Lord Kitchener auditorium, National Academy for the Performing Arts (NAPA) on Tuesday night was a manifestation of professionalism in the area of music and folk dance... Korean Ambassador Wonkun Hwang was so thrilled about the number of patrons who turned out to the concert that he said, We never have any problems in getting the auditorium filled when the Embassy puts on a Korean concert. The hour and a half performance began with a fanfare of colour and drums and movement as the performers marched trough audience with traditional drums playing an ensemble called Gilgut-Pungmulnori which is a farmers band musical. |The performances were put on by the Korean Traditional Performing Arts Association (KTPAA) which is based in New York, and has been performing throughout the United States for the past 20 years. The six-member group is led by Sue-Yeon Park who has received several awards from different countries. Grabbing the attention of the patrons was the saenghwang, a Korean instrument made from 17 bamboo poles, each having its own sound. Highlight of the evenings performance was the Buchae-chum (Fan Dance) which brought out the exuberance and colour of Korean fans displayed with colourful costumes and shifting geometrical designs set in a garden with flowers. Coming closer home Amazing Grace and Beatles Medley played on Korean instruments provoked sustained applause from the crowd. To end what patrons described as an evening of mastery in dance and song and a unique experience of traditional Korean music, the concert concluded with the Korean Ambassador and a select number of patrons appearing on stage to take part in Arirang, a Korean folk song regarded as the unofficial anthem of Korea. Attending the performance were Arts and Multiculturalism Minister Minister Lincoln Douglas, ambassadors from different countries and a wide cross section of music and dance lovers. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/back-ah-yard-at-mas-camp/article_3ef70197-a5d5-5744-a43b-67b0046cf76e.html", "TITLE": " Back-Ah-Yard At Mas Camp ", "DATE": "Jul 29, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The Back-Ah-Yard cultural movement from Point Fortin will on Wednesday present, at the Mas Camp Pub, Woodbrook, an event titled Mystic At Mas Camp PubBack-Ah-Yard In Town from 8.30 p.m. The concert will feature performances by Brother Valentino, Maximus Dan, Brother Resistance, Shakeela, Muhummad Muwakil, Damian Melville, Daryl \"D Saint\" Mendoza, Gitta Dan, Lou Lyons and Freetown Collective along with other artistes. All proceeds will go toward the staging of a series of concerts titled Nurture the Youth at The Nest Children's Home in Kingston, Jamaica, and The Bel Air Children's Home in St George's, Grenada, between August 14 and 28. Led by artiste Dixie Ann \"Shakeela\" Joseph, Back-Ah-Yard was established in 2006 for the purpose of providing a space for developing artistes as well as to encourage the nation's youth to appreciate local culture and talent. Located at Boodoo Street, Point Fortin the movement has extended its reach into other areas of Trinidad and Tobago as well as into Grenada and Jamaica. In the five years since its inception, Back-Ah-Yard has presented a number of young calypsonians, rapso artistes, instrumentalists, poets, dancers and others in shows locally and abroad. Many of the members of the Back-Ah-Yard movement give of their time and talent freely to assist young people in expressing their own art, which is a main part of their philosophy and motto, Inspire Someone. Among the projects the group has undertaken is the Nurture the Youth concert, which was attended by 250 pupils from eight primary schools in Point Fortin during the borough's 30th anniversary Borough Day celebrations last year. In November last year, the Nurture The Youth concert took place at the Nest Children's Home run by the Salvation Army at its headquarters at Mannings Hill Road, Kingston, Jamaica. This was done by Back-Ah-Yard in collaboration with the Trinidad and Tobago Entertainment Company. The concert was also presented on April 20 this year at the Fanny Village Community Centre, where 200 primary and secondary school pupils attended. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/pan-trinbago-official-calls-for-more-local-content/article_297994e6-9b78-5589-9335-b345b72bba17.html", "TITLE": " Pan Trinbago official calls for more local content ", "DATE": "Nov 7, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " Even as Pan Trinbago official Michael Joseph was issuing a call for citizens to include local content in programmes, none of the 17 junior Sanfest Pan finalists played a local tune at Skinner Park, San Fernando, yesterday. Joseph, chairman of Pan Trinbago's South Central Zone, said the people of Trinidad and Tobago should be proud of their own culture rather than to promote the influences coming out of North America. Joseph was speaking at the 43rd annual NGC Sanfest Pan Finals, dubbed, De Arts and Culture \u2013 Essential to Life, held at Skinner Park. Joseph noted that recently when commuting on the water taxi, he did not hear a single track by any local person on the airwaves. \"The kind of entertainment on the ferry was not even a chutney, pan or soca. It was all about American music.\" He said Pan Trinbago alone cannot do everything to promote the steelpan and commended the promoters who took the initiative to include pan in the Sanfest competition. Even as the ten primary schools and seven secondary schools lined up for the competition, not one arrangement was done with the use of a piece by a local performer. Forest Reserve Anglican Primary School played Lionel Richie's \"All Night Long\" and retained the title for a third consecutive year. They were followed by runner-up Success Roman Catholic School, which played \"Never Can Say Goodbye\" and Grant Memorial Presbyterian School which also played \"Never Can Say Goodbye\" and came third. In the secondary school category, St Benedicts' College won with Aretha Franklin's classic \"Respect\". Success Laventille Secondary School also played \"All Night Long\" and finished second and San Fernando East Secondary School placed third with the arrangement of the late Whitney Houston's \"One Moment in Time\". Boodramsingh, a former champion apprentice congratulated Butcher on his achievement. Boodramsingh, last year\u0092s champion rider, is now two wins behind leader, Wilmer Galviz with the final raceday, the Boxing Day ten-race card, being the decider. \u0097Photo: DAVID WIGHT CHAMP AND APPRENTICE: Defending champion jockey, Brian Boodramsingh, right, and soon to be crowned champion apprentice, David Butcher, at Wednesday\u0092s Apprentice Jockeys Graduation ceremony for the Class of 2013, held in the Racehorse Owners Association room, Santa Rosa Park, in Arima. Boodramsingh, a former champion apprentice congratulated Butcher on his achievement. Boodramsingh, last year\u0092s champion rider, is now two wins behind leader, Wilmer Galviz with the final raceday, the Boxing Day ten-race card, being the decider. \u0097Photo: DAVID WIGHT It was not the sort of scene that might appear on our prime time news channels. But the wonders of modern technology sometimes transmit the stark reality of the cruelty and barbarity of some contemporary human cultures. In one on-line English newspaper there was a brief video clip of a public daylight whipping of a woman by more than one policeman in Somalia. No details were ventured on the \"crime\" for which she was whipped. She was fully clothed in what I imagine to be an enforced dress code complete with head covering, ordered to sit on the ground surrounded by men, while two uniformed policemen took turns whipping her, not with canes but with long corded whip. The scene was interjected with her screams. As disgusting as the scene was the more abhorrent was the behaviour of the two policemen. When she defensively grabbed hold of the whip, another policeman emerged behind her with his whip and commenced whipping her across her back, both policemen cackling with laughter at her screams. The culture of the country, I suppose. The word \"culture\"it has so many meanings. The primary meaning however refers to the collective patterns of socially transmitted behaviour of human communities, including beliefs, languages, history, institutions, recreation, arts, science, commerce, laws and governance and so on. It must be noted, however, that cultures may differ markedly and often change. When one hears the word culture in the case of T&T it is more often understood to mean either entertainment of some form or folk and religious ways. But if we accept the primary meaning of the word we must accept that our culture must necessarily include many negatives. Compared with many T&T is supposedly highly corrupt, contemptuous of law, with disgusting road manners, cares little for the environment, littering and degrading, generating much noise and disorder, with most of our national institutions failing in their responsibilities to citizens. The one thing that continues to intrigue about our culture is the theme that Kevin Baldeosingh from time to time so patiently and clinically explains, the broad general correlation between religiosity and crime levels in different countries. For all the religiosity of T&T and the voluminous prayers that fly up to Heaven each day we continue to be a noisy, disordered, lawless, violent and crime-ridden society. We often continue to hear that we are a multicultural and multi-religious society, sometimes even with a sense of awe. On the other hand there is no doubt that cultures, including their subsets, can often bind peoples beneficially and support some measure of order, even as there may be strong divisions in that culture. At the same time there can hardly have any human culture where the process of binding does not involve some degree of coercion, in many cases extremely violent coercion. Religions may do it in different ways, some through the indoctrination from early childhood that may involve threats of one kind or another, or, through religious law that in some cases prescribes the death penalty for individual behaviours that would normally be ignored in other cultures. A Christian woman in Pakistan is sentenced to death for the \"crime\" of blasphemy the \"evidence\" being given by a group of Muslim women. Blasphemy is still on our law books as a criminal offence but is now ignored, whereas in Pakistan it may attract the death penalty as was recently reported. Perhaps some will note the irony of blasphemy being in some countries blasphemy against the dominant national religionin T&T against Christianity and in Pakistan against Islam. Perhaps some of the core values of the major religions may be shared, even by atheists and agnostics. These values however are few. It is when you get down to the broader customs, rituals and dictates of these that we see the divisive and exploitative methods of religions. It is not for a moment that I assume that religion or religions will disappear. But to survive in a more liberal world each religion or subset must use every possible device to maintain market share of the pool of available individuals, in some cases with promises and in others with repression. But can any Trinbagonian imagine living in a theocratic state and living under barbaric religious laws. T&T for all its faults is extremely lucky in that its governance has been in the traditions of the coloniser. We are what we are largely because of our history and culture that has been derived from western parliamentary systems that for the past few centuries have managed progressively to contain and diminish the powers of the Christian churches, with governments becoming progressively more secular. But even in some cultures as subsets continue to slaughter each other in the finest tradition of Christian religious violence of the past, now referred to as sectarian violence where Muslims slaughter Muslims, I imagine that some male Trinis might actually have enjoyed the public whipping of a woman. * Julian Kenny, chairman of the Environmental Management Authority, is a biologist and natural history author. He is a former UWI Professor of Zoology and Independent Senator. Prime Minister Patrick Manning made the announcement on Sunday night during his address to the nation on Government's efforts to prevent the country from going into a recession. Pan Trinbago president Patrick Arnold says culture is not a priority in this country therefore the move was not surprising to him. \"I don't think we treat culture in the right way. We don't have proper venues for shows and we need venues. \"We had our festival (National Steelband Music Festival Pan Is Beautiful XI) at the Jean Pierre Complex last night (Sunday) which was in a terrible condition, the lighting was terrible.\" See Page 7. Arnold said he hoped that the Academy of the Performing Arts, at Princess Building Grounds which is still under construction can be used for events. President of the Trinbago Unified Calypsonians Association (TUCO) Franz \"Delamo\" Lambkin added: \"We understand the economic situation so we have to go with what was announced. But our view is that the priority was mixed up and the Carnival Centre should have been built before the Academy was built.\" And President of the National Carnival Bands Association (NCBA) Owen Hinds said he will make an announcement on the decision after his members meet later this week. \"Preparations for Carnival 2009 have already started taking place. The Parade of Bands remains on the road but we want to know if we could go back to the Savannah. All this will be discussed at the meeting,\" he said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-time-is-right-for-the-caribbean-region/article_9826a17e-ea41-5cef-bdc3-9eda316b6f1c.html", "TITLE": " The time is right for the Caribbean region... ", "DATE": "Oct 3, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "From left, BGTT's Derek Hudson, Viviana Prieto, Gillian Hudson, and Atlantic's outgoing CEO Oscar Prieto share a laugh. From left, BGTT's Derek Hudson, Viviana Prieto, Gillian Hudson, and Atlantic's outgoing CEO Oscar Prieto share a laugh. Keith Khan, a London-based artist of Trinidadian parentage, impressed a large audience at a one-day conference on culture and tourism held at the Chaguaramas Convention Centre last Tuesday, with a detailed presentation, supported by visual images of the work he has been doing in London and elsewhere, including making use of Notting Hill carnival at various presentations. When I sought to interview Khan, it turned out he was already on the verge of his return trip to London. So he agreed to answer some questions that I e-mailed him. The result is the following interview: Q: Can you provide some information on what you've described as your \"Trinidadian heritage\" A: My father's family are Khans from Fyzabad, and my mother's are Mohammeds from Siparia. My parents came to the UK in the early sixtiesfor further education. But that means I still have plenty of aunties and uncles in TrinidadI think on both sides of the family there were about 14 brothers and sisters which means there are enough cousins spread throughout the world. Your age Marital status I'm 42 and unmarried. Could you elaborate on your involvement with the London Olympiad of 2012 and other major projects with which you've been associated I held the post of head of culture for the London Olympics for two years. Prior to that I was part of the bid team. My role was to develop a \"Cultural Olympiad\" with a range of cultural projects to complement the Olympic Games. This is across all sectors, music, museums, galleries, Shakespeare, online. All of these schemes are now being delivered by major UK agencies such as the BBC, the RSC (Royal Shakespeare Company) to name a few. I also created a day called \"Open\" where cultural institutions, places of cultural productionsuch as digital or music studios open their doors to people who might want to learn or participate in the Olympics. I also prepared a cross-cutting plan for young people across the Olympic portfolio as well as a proposition for the \"Festival of Carnivals\". Prior to this, I was chief executive officer of the Rich Mix Cultural Foundation, which involved managing the start-up and a capital build project worth 28 million pounds. It has three cinemas, with the BBC London Studio as anchor tenants, as well as a number of musical and design-focused creative industries. It was a London and Arts Council initiative to provide a sustainable building in the East End of London. Rich Mix is the first in the \"new style\" of cultural institutions that goes beyond opera and visual art and looks at the digital generation. Rich Mix is a very cool place, club nights, programmes around sport and very accessible. I had the opportunity to work with Gilberto Gil, the renowned Brazilian artist and former minister of culture, and we sent digital artists into Brazil to help them capacity build their artists, as well as build Brazil's first \"Pontos du Cultura\" in London. It was really good to create jobs for local people with international aspirations. Before Rich Mix, I was a founding partner of an arts company called \"Moti Roti\", which is still running. The last show I created with them was Aladeen. It was a big hit in New York and around the world. Aladeen told the story of the call-centre phenomenon in India, within a sophisticated show which integrated live feeds and technology on stage. Moti Roti is currently engaged, under the directorship of Ali Zaidi, with a range of film and food projects between India, Pakistan and the UK. I'm quite proud this company has been a vehicle for 14 years of a vast range of cultural projects, including the Commonwealth Parade for the Queen's Golden Jubilee and the show Moti Roti, which was the first Bollywood musical on stage. And that was back in 1991! What was the main purpose of your return home this time around And when are you likely to visit us next I was a guest of the Ministry of Tourism; Minister Joseph Ross invited me to share my knowledge and expertise about how culture and creativity can be used to diversify T&T's tourism portfolio. This agenda is one Josanne Leonard has been working on for a number of years now, and I hope Trinidad and Tobago does widen its scope. There seems to be a lot of infrastructure, such as the new academies for the performing arts in Port of Spain and San Fernando. It will be important that the vision for these are placed on the world stage, as well as a local resource. They will need great content and should be mapped into a long-term strategy, particularly considering the opportunity the Caribbean hopes to exploit through the Special Protocol on Cultural Cooperation in the EPA signed with the EU. Trinidad and Tobago has an abundance of cultural assetsa rich cultural heritage, pan, Carnival, amazing food, design and digital, and I hope the Government and State-purpose agencies can work together to ensure the country capitalises on this. The conference organised by Josanne Leonard was amazing. It was interesting how an international consultant of Caribbean heritage and home-grown regional consultants were combined to contribute to these important discussions. It was a brilliant stroke by the ministry because often we rely on \"others\" and not ourselves to validate our development and business agendas. The minister gets full marks for using our intellectual capital. The conference also confirmed in my mind that there is such a strong series of tangible opportunities that need to be capitalised on as a joint folio between your cultural and tourism ministries. Last year, I did a similar visit to Australia, and there (over a five-day period), I visited two cities, Sydney and Melbourne, and spoke to the city, the state and a range of local artists. Three presentations per city! And at all levels. This was under the auspices of the Australian government and the Australia Arts Council. They have clearly listened to some of the propositions, and as a result, I will be developing artistic projects with and from Australia. Let's hope that Trinidad and Tobago and the Caribbean does the same thing. What is your current status Over the past two years with LOCOG (London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games), I stepped away briefly from my creative practice as a director/artist to get right under the skin of the arts ecology to try and create wide opportunities for artists and other creatives under the Cultural Olympiad banner. I was happy to do that because it gave me an intimate knowledge of working in the wider governmental area. Now, the time is right for me to move back into the creative work. As such, I have created a new company called D Lime, which is currently developing a range of arts and entertainment projects and ideas. At the top of the list is an accordion of programmes and events focused on the Caribbean. These include a big musical and theatrical spectral, an orchestra exchange (with steelband), film and fashion exhibitions and some amazing music concerts. Another current project is a collaboration with the Department for Climate Change (DECC) to identify how artistes can really bring alive this crucial issue of climate change to a wider audience. I've also been working as part of an international steering group for the Commonwealth Foundation, under the chairship of Baroness Lola Young, preparing a Declaration on Culture and Development for the CHOGM (Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting) in November. If I am lucky, I will be back home in November for that announcement. You said at your presentation at the tourism conference that you didn't see enough Caribbean products that could live up to \"international standards\". What sort of products were you referring to Could you elaborate on that And what do you think can be done to improve this Having been involved in the arts in London for a 20-year stretch, I have seen diversity projects come and go. I'm not talking about the commercial music success of artistes like Eddy Grant, Bob Marley, Billy Ocean and others like Shaggy, Sean Paul and Rihanna. Or even literature (of a particular era) where the region has made such a great impact but has not been able to realise more mainstream appeal for a number of reasons, including distribution and access to venues. From my own experience, a lot of small, locally-focused pieces come in from the region, and often, they are sold to local diaspora audiences. While these are crucial markets, (plural because the community is fragmented), I still live to see real crossover, high-end, well-delivered cultural projects. I would like to see a range of contemporary artistic outputs that reflect the Trinidad and Tobago I know, and not just heritage or Carnival projects which are not well funded or promoted and, thus, are not able to cross over. I believe that Caribbean work needs to be better produced and curated, so it can sit proudly along other countries that are doing so much to promote their cultures. For example, look at Nigeria or India, both countries have really created such a range of exciting projects that have completely shifted the global perception of these countries. I believe the time is ripe for the Caribbean region to create some major shows that can sit and run for seasons in the West End or Broadway. Really sophisticated music projects that can validate our steelband alongside orchestras, so the world can experience what the Caribbean offers. Much of what comes to Europe from the region sometimes compounds stereotypes. The exception seems to be visual arts where some truly breathtaking artists have been profiled. Of course, all of this depends on Trinidad and Tobago itself making a sea change jump in developing this. The government has to support artists with enough freedom so that they are given the power and condition to create. Artists have to be critical and focus on doing great work, and the industry professionals to market and promote must be engaged. My goal with D Lime is to create this artistic and business bridge between the Caribbean and the UK. Do you work with Trinidadians in London There are Trinidadians everywhere! At the Olympics, there are a few Jamaicans in high positions. For many years, I have worked with carnival in Notting HillYaa Asatewaa and South connectionsso I've worked with some great Caribbean talent that way. What is the Trinidad and Tobago image like out there in London Has our virulent crime rate been spoiling or affecting that image in any way I think it needs a bit of a makeover. The Tobago attacks have really dented the view in the UK, and Trinidadian security issues need to be resolved. Within the artistic communities, however, I think there is a good view and excitement, even about the creative imagination and talent that exists, so it would be a shame not to use this right now. Profiling T&T and the region through its culture is really the leap that needs to be made now. With reference to the 2012 cultural programme in which you said you wanted to have a major Caribbean input, could you explain what this is all about And what kind of \"cultural input\" you will be looking for The athletic prowess of the Caribbean will be very present throughout the Olympics. The world is on fire with Bolt, Thompson and the Caribbean posse of athletes. At D Lime, we want to work with Caribbean artistes, creatives and ministries of culture and tourism to explore this brand using Caribbean music, digital media and projection, and spoken word and dance. And we hope to incorporate archive media by documenting everything we do, so it is part of a very contemporary performance. At present, D Lime is in discussion with a top multi-arts venue in London to produce a major exhibition focused on Caribbean aesthetics (fashion, film, art, architecture, music etc). It will include a music exchange and artistic capacity-building between London and the Caribbean. This is looking to 2012 with a series of smaller events in the run-up to the Games. The goal is to present these highly-polished and well-produced events, exhibitions and shows brought together with the best of talent from the region, under my artistic leadership. I'm really excited about being able to use years of artistic and business contacts and networks to brand T&T and the Caribbean, given the window of the Olympics. Now it's just for regional governments and businesses to move more decisively, understanding that the rest of the world plans ahead strategically. While the Caribbean is late, there is a lot that can be achieved with the right support because T&T and the region is playing catch-up! What advice would you offer to young people in general and young artists in particular Make sure that you focus on excellence in creativity or whatever it is you do; be digitally visible and look at developing markets outside of Europe and North America. Work hard; there are no shortcuts or overnight successes. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/proposals-and-promises-for-culture/article_1f3e817a-1963-534e-af27-4fac9c1ff342.html", "TITLE": " Proposals and promises for culture ", "DATE": "Sep 30, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "There was little in the already tiny bag of goodies for the arts and culture fraternity in the national budget revealed yesterday by Finance Minister Larry Howai. Whatever was announced in the nine paragraphs devoted to the \"Creative Industries\" consisted mainly of proposed tax incentives and duty free allowances for investors in the arts, entertainment and culture arenas and also included the architectural design and software industries. Howai said the Government is seeking to establish Trinidad and Tobago as a premier film and television production centre and will therefore expand whatever incentives towards achieving this are already in place. At present, the main incentive is a cash rebate of up to 35 per cent to film producers using Trinidad and Tobago as a location, but this has not brought in as many foreign filmmakers using here as a location as was hoped. There is also a tax break of 150 per cent up to $2 million for investment in local films and investment in other local endeavours by corporate or private entities. This, however, is yet to be exploited as the forms and certificates to obtain this are not available. Howai's proposal of a new incentive takes the form of a tax deduction for international filmmakers as well as local producers, which is similar to the tax incentive that is already in place. The Minister proposes to implement this by January 2013, saying he hopes it will encourage those involved in the various creative industries to develop their skills and products to world-class standards. \"To boost the film sub-sector I propose to expand the current incentives which are currently available to the film sub-sector. We have now put in place the infrastructure for expanding and developing the Arts and Creative Industries. The performing and visual arts, the literary and fashion industries, architectural design and software industries are all being encouraged to become world-class. The culture shift to arts and creativity would mean not only having world-class artistes but also mean that such artistes would have sustainable livelihoods,\" said Howai. \"Effective January 1, 2013, I propose to implement for persons in the creative industry, the following tax incentives currently available to sponsors and producers: 150 per cent tax deduction up to a maximum of $3 million for the corporate sponsorship of nationals in the local fashion industry; 150 per cent tax deduction up to a maximum of $3 million for the corporate sponsorship of audio, visual or video productions for the purpose of local education or local entertainment; and 150 per cent tax deduction up to a maximum of $3 million may be claimed by local production companies in respect of their own productions,\" he added. There was no mention of investment in the construction of much-needed new performing venues for theatre, concerts or other performing arts. Howai did, however, say a Ramleela Centre will soon be established and this \"with its street theatre, will contribute to the continuing development of the arts and culture of our cosmopolitan society\". The Ramleela Centre in question is to be constructed at the Divali Nagar site in Chaguanas where training will be provided to people wishing to participate in the annual Ramleela street theatre. However, this is only one of other such venues that the recently-incorporated National Ramleela Council intends to establish. Other incentives towards investment in the creative industries and arts and culture arena include the zero rating of Value Added Tax and duties on the importation of equipment and material, these to be determined by the Government. \"During the fiscal year 2013, the Minister of Trade, Industry and Investment will collaborate with the Chamber of Commerce to establish the necessary guarantee with the Comptroller of Customs and Excise in order to facilitate relief from customs duty under the carnet system, for persons in the creative industries. I propose to implement for persons in the creative industries, in particular the film industry, a regime to allow them to import into Trinidad and Tobago equipment and film-specific goods duty free,\" said Howai. \"I propose to implement for persons in the creative industries, the zero-rating of Value Added Tax on machinery and equipment. The Ministry of Trade, Industry and Investment will collaborate with persons in the creative industry to determine the goods that should be zero-rated,\" he said. Bruce Paddington, founder of the Trinidad and Tobago Film Festival and respected filmmaker, told the Express he is happy over the adjusted incentives and looks forward to local companies deciding to invest in film production. He said he would have liked the cash back to have been increased from 35 per cent to 40 per cent, but he is still pleased with what has been offered and proposed by Minister Howai. \"This one is good, very positive. That's what the stakeholders have been asking for the removal of Value Added Tax and duties on lights, cameras and other equipment. They will have to do the regulations, but this is a dream come true for the local filmmakers. \"I am also happy that the limit on the tax break has been raised to $3 million and I am hopeful that this will stimulate the private sector to invest in local filmmaking. I would have liked to see the cash back raised to 40 per cent and possibly linked to the use of local labour and talent. But I'm thankful,\" said Paddington. PENSIVE: Deputy principal, UWI, St Augustine, Rhoda Reddock, from left, head of Department DCFA, UWI, Jessel Murray, and dean of Humanities and Education, Funso Aiyejina. \u0097Photos: Wayne Bowman 'GURU': Jamaica's Director of Culture, Sydney Bartley, delivers the keynote address at Friday's THNK conference at UWI, St Augustine. The Department of Creative and Festival Arts at the University of the West Indies, St Augustine, on Friday hosted the second edition of its annual THNK conference at the Faculty of Engineering. The conference series examines various facets of local culture, festival and performance arts and explores how can they be effectively employed towards the social, aesthetic and financial benefits of the people. Conceptualised by cultural researcher Dr Suzanne Burke, THNK also dissects Government policy on culture, identifying areas where there may be shortfalls and things that may have been overlooked. Through panel discussions and lecture presentations, ideas are compiled and documented. The papers are made available for researchers and those responsible for formulating policy on the local entertainment industry, culture and festival arts. At the opening session of this year's THNK, the keynote address, titled \"The Role of Culture in Caribbean Development\", was presented by Jamaica's Director of Culture, Sydney Bartley, who is hailed as a guru of culture throughout the Caribbean and beyond. Bartley noted that, throughout the Caribbean, influences from Europe and America overpower the cultures of the islands, overshadowing the identities of the peoples. In one of his examples of this, Bartley quoted Bob Marley's \"No Woman No Cry\" to show how the people have been changed by invasive foreign influences. \"I remember when we used to sit in a government yard in Trench Town. And then Georgie would make the fire light, log wood burning through the night. Then we would cook cornmeal porridge of which I'll share with you,\" sang Bartley, who was joined by some in the audience. Bartley then explained that Marley's lyrics referenced what life was like in the Caribbean then when men, elders and youth alike used to sit together and reason. He said women did not cry when men sat and talked, conversed, worked things out instead of shooting one another, even in hard times. When men sit together and observe women don't cry, Bartley said. Bartley also likened the lyric on sharing the cornmeal porridge to the days when neighbours shared a cup of sugar and other things with one another. Society now teaches people to lock into themselves and not interact with their neighbours, he said. Bartley said community living was how the slaves brought here survived mentally because, after the entire day in the fields, at night they ate together in the barrack yard and shared stories, drummed and danced. Bartley said the two things Caribbean people excel the most in, sport and culture, are designated as extracurricular activities. He said this is the biggest failure of the Caribbean education system and even went on to knock the university system, saying it continues to put the proverbial cart before the horse where sport and the arts are concerned. Bartley said if an artiste such as Machel Montano were to decide to pursue university studies here in the Caribbean now he would have to start at the beginning in spite of his years of success and achievements. The right thing to do, Bartley said, would be to allow Montano credits for what he has accomplished throughout the years he has been doing his music. Bartley said the system has to be changed to serve the people of the Caribbean specifically so we can enjoy the maximum benefits of what we possess. Bartley said nothing cultural has ever come out of universities because it's the grassroots people who have created their cultural identities. Therefore, said Bartley, any government-formulated cultural policy and cultural education plan must consider the cultural identity of the people. Bartley said how the people through the ages have healed themselves using herbs and the things of nature, to how they made use of limited financial and other resources, has shaped the culture and seen them survive. An interesting moment in Bartley's speech was his invitation to the participants to join him in singing Bob Marley's \"Redemption Song\", which everyone did heartedly. This Bartley did to drive home the point that it is by remembering who we are as a united Caribbean people that will make us prosper. Bartley also in his presentation celebrated the music of the Mighty Sparrow and David Rudder as artistes who, like Marley, have helped the Caribbean people sing their own songs despite being bombarded by foreign cultures. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/celebrating-communities-and-culture/article_9bf2cd42-20fb-5ee5-b80c-f3f09a710c16.html", "TITLE": " Celebrating communities and culture ", "DATE": "Jun 5, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "Photos: Kerron Riley IN FULL GROOVE: Phase II Pan Groove will also participate in WeBeat 2013. \u0097Photo: Robert Taylor Photos: Kerron Riley IN FULL GROOVE: Phase II Pan Groove will also participate in WeBeat 2013. \u0097Photo: Robert Taylor After almost being cancelled over the lack of funding the WeBeat Festival of arts, culture and sport in St James kicks off tonight with the WeBeat Honourees Awards Ceremony and Dinner at the Lion's Cultural Centre, Fitzblackman Drive, Woodbrook. Hosted by the St James Community Improvement Committee, producers of WeBeat, the event is this year in honour of Dr Michael Alleyne and Mannie Dookie. Alleyne is the widely acclaimed architect of the present national education system which included the creation of the Junior Secondary School and the \"double shift\" system. He was the vice-principal at St George's College, principal at Tunapuna Government Secondary School and founding principal of South East Port of Spain Government Secondary School. Dookie was probably the most famous Trinidad and Tobago athlete of his time and his name will remain in the history of local athletics because he was a top-class long-distance runner and because he was a pioneer, the first athlete to represent the country in international athletics. One of the things that became his trade mark was that he never liked running in shoes for which he became known as \"the bare-footed runner\". The awards ceremony begins a week of activities and events celebrating the accomplishments of the people of St James and also providing a platform from which residents can display their skills, talents and even business acumen. There will also be public forums and discussions on the history and development of the community as well as informative sessions on disaster preparedness open to the general public. The St James Amphitheatre will be the venue where a number of cultural shows, some free to the public, others requiring admission prices will take place. On Sunday for instance there will be the WeTreat at the Amphitheatre where children 12 years old and under from the area will be provided with refreshments and also be treated to various fun activities and be entertained by performers including several steel orchestras such as St James Tripolians, Xcite Steelband and Scrunters Pan Groove. On Wednesday there will be a concert titled, Caribbean Beat featuring Pelham Goddard and Roots with special guest, reigning International Power Soca Monarch and National Road March Champion, SuperBlue who will himself have a couple of surprises in store for the patrons. The following night will see the show titled, Pan Explosion taking place at the same venue where Republic Bank Exodus, Solo Harmonites with pianist, Louis Nurse, White Oak Starlift and the St James Tripolians steel orchestras will perform. The always popular, We Vintage Kaiso show comes off at the Amphitheatre on Friday with performances by Baron, Stalin, Scrunter, Ras Kommanda, Bally, Explainer, Johnny King and Poser, with Nikki Crosby serving as host. The following night will see the grand steelband parade along the Western Main Road beginning at 7 p.m. and ending at 2 a.m. There will be 16 steelbands from across the island participating and people are invited to come and jump up to pan music all night and even wear their Carnival costumes if they please. The line-up of steel orchestras includes: RBL Exodus, Cal Invaders, Trinidad Pan Connoisseurs, White Oak Starlift, Petrotrin Phase II Pan Groove, Rhapsody, Valley Harps, Humming Bird Pan Groove, Old Tech Steel Orchestra, Scrunters Pan Groove, St James Tripolians, Carib Woodbrook Playboyz, Musical Gems, Havard Harps, Brimblers, La Creole Pan Groove and Longdenville Claytones. WeBeat 2013 comes to a close on Sunday with the WeFilm Night at the Amphitheatre from 7 p.m. This is being presented in collaboration with the Trinidad and Tobago Film Festival. Other events taking place during the week includes the Health Day on Monday, the WeTalk Sidewalk Historian Talk Show on the same day at the Amphitheatre from 7 p.m., and the WeBeat Football Game on Wednesday at the St James Police Barracks. The Arima Fest 2013 opened yesterday with an art exhibition titled, A Collector's Dream at the Borough's Town Hall. This will run until June 24. The three months of activities are in celebration of Arima's status as a Borough having been proclaimed 125 years ago. Although a schedule of events has been released by the Mayor's office details on most of them especially the cultural events are still sketchy for the most part. Among the main events of Arima Fest is the Miss Arima Pageant Royale on July 13 at the Arima New Government Primary School in which several young women from Arima and environs will compete to be crowned Miss Arima and reign over the festival from that night. The art of box cart making and driving was at one time very popular in the Borough and occupied much of the time of children during the Easter and August vacation periods. The Borough Counsel is reviving this and will host a Box Cart Derby on July 14. The following Sunday, July 21 will see a Grand Arima Fest Food Fair taking place at the public car park near the Velodrome. Booths will offer a wide assortment of foods including dishes from the First Peoples (Carib) Community as well as from residents from the Borough's Spanish, East Indian, Chinese, Syrian/Lebanese, African and Creole heritage communities. This has, since its inception about three years ago, become one of the very popular events that features not only great food, but live entertainment. There is also always a tasty selection of chows including mango, pineapple and plum. Of course the main event is the Carib Santa Rosa Carib Festival on August 25, which draws people from throughout the island including Tobago. Arimians living abroad also come home from at least the week before to be a part of this tradition. Other events during Arima Fest includes the Arima Parangrama (July 26), Cannon Blast (August 1), Military Parade (August 4) and the Street Festival with Steelbands (August 10). {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/taking-back-our-culture/article_a585f069-50a0-5aac-b4cd-1c5e36719682.html", "TITLE": " Taking Back Our Culture ", "DATE": "Aug 6, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " CROP KING: Gabby performs \"Ole Ashe\" to win the 2010 Barbados Calypso Monarch title at the Pic-O-De-Crop finals. CROP KING: Gabby performs \"Ole Ashe\" to win the 2010 Barbados Calypso Monarch title at the Pic-O-De-Crop finals. Trinidadians for decades made little of the carnivals in the small islands saying those festivals can't compare to the greatest show on earth, Trinidad Carnival. The stakeholders of Trinidad Carnival now fear that other territories, including other Caribbean islands, are producing carnivals that seem more attractive to people around the world. The Ministry of Arts and Multiculturalism, National Carnival Bands Association and Trinidad and Tobago Entertainment Company are now seeking to get Carnival back on an even keel after several years of a downward spiral. They are also working on branding all Trinidad-styled carnivals around the world as originating in Trinidad. Hopefully it's not too little, too late. One example of Trinidad Carnival being beaten is the Pic-O-De-Crop National Calypso Monarch finals in Barbados during the just concluded Crop Over celebrations there. The show took place at the Kensington Oval and was attended by over 12,000 people. The venue was completely rebuilt for the 2007 Cricket World Cup tournament and is a state of the art sport facility that is also used for cultural events. The Pic-O-De-Crop was produced by the Barbados National Cultural Foundation (BNCF), which employed the best resources available to produce a show designed to be broadcast live and recorded on DVD. The calypsonians performed from on a large domed stage with the latest in lighting and video effects technology that was used to enhance every moment of the show. The sound system was also top of the line and as soon as there were any problems the crew dealt with them so the performances were not severely affected. There were 10 finalists in the Pic-O-De-Crop finals, each singing two songs. The majority of calypsoes were political commentary, with a couple gospelypso and social commentary in the mix. There were also calypsoes attacking Red Plastic Bag who was defending his title on the night and if he had won would have set the record for capturing the title ten times. In fact, the calypsonian that placed second, Adrian Clarke who was one of the two competitors the majority of patrons supported to win the competition sang \"No Red Plastic Bag Day,\" in which he called on Bajans to go green and stop using plastic bags, especially red ones. His other song, \"Crowd Response\" was about how audiences at calypso competitions influence the decisions of the judges by their response to performances. TC who was also a favourite for the title sang in round one \"Out Of Control\" following that up with \"Stimulus\" in round two. Several hundred patrons booed when it was announced that she tied for fifth place with Andy \"Blood\" Armstrong. The people booed even harder when it was revealed that Gabby won the title singing \"Haiti,\" a tribute to the achievements of the Haitian people since they liberated themselves from slavery and French rule in the 19th century. His second song, \"Ole Ashe,\" was a samba infused calypso most people did not seem to grasp. Gabby took offense to people questioning whether or not the song was a calypso, going as far as assaulting a television/radio journalist, Anthony \"Admiral\" Nelson during the Cohobblopot show because Nelson raised questions about the song and Gabby's performance of it at the finals. Gabby also got irritated during a press conference held at the Barbados Hilton on July 31 when Trinidad radio personality, Sterling Henderson asked about people's dislike of the song. The nine-time monarch said people who dislike the song do not have an ear for music. Back to the production of the Pic-O-De-Crop; the show ran on time and smoothly despite heavy rainfall during the day. The cricket field and pitch were completely covered by protective rubber matting that allowed the grass to breathe. Hosted by the comedian/calypsonian, Mac Fingall the show for the first time featured only the calypso competition. The King and Queen competition was cancelled because there were only three sets of kings and queens of a quality the BNCF deemed worthy of competition. So it was decided that it was best that the competition be axed-for this year at least. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/before-there-was-bollywood/article_4d88fb6a-0a83-5806-a79e-65d93129536b.html", "TITLE": " before there was bollywood ", "DATE": "Nov 19, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "GETTING HELP: Adrian Barath ON DISPLAY: Indian High Commissioner, Malay Mishra walks Parliamentary secretary in the Ministry of Arts and Multiculturalism, Nela Khan through an exhibition on the history of Indian cinema. GETTING HELP: Adrian Barath ON DISPLAY: Indian High Commissioner, Malay Mishra walks Parliamentary secretary in the Ministry of Arts and Multiculturalism, Nela Khan through an exhibition on the history of Indian cinema. In saris and suits they came, specially invited guests and lovers of Indian cinema for an historic first at MovieTowne, Port of Spain. It was a milestone moment for the Indian diaspora, a people who once had to settle for movies shown in a tent using a Holmes projector now had their own film festival at the premier entertainment complex in North Trinidad. There are very few who may remember, some 75 years ago when the first ever Filmi in Trinidad, Bala Joban captivated and delighted locals starved for a taste of early Indian cinema. Indian movies would later be seen in cinemas, drive-ins and in movie rental clubs, although without subtitles. Unfortunately, with the advent of DVD technology and rampant piracy, Filmi audiences have now shrunk to mere handfuls. The Festival includes the films Dharm, Kanchivaram, Kutty Srank, Gulabi Talkies, Dulha Mil Gaya, Harish Chandrachi Factory, Dev D, The White Elephant, Janala, Haat: The Weekly Bazaar and Little Zizou. On opening night the movie Dev D was shown. It is a modern-day interpretation of Sarat Chandra Chattopadhyay's classic Bengali novel \"Devdas\". In the movie, Dev (Abhay Deol) is the son of a rich Punjabi businessman. He and Paro (Mahi Gill) are childhood sweethearts. But Dev, insecure arrogant, does not acknowledge Paro's feelings and rides her over frivolous issues. Dev is sent to London as a punishment and to further his studies. This, ironically intensifies their love for each other. However when Dev hears rumours about Paro, he shuns her. A broken, hurt Paro turns her back on Dev and agrees to marry whoever her parents choose. On her wedding day, Dev learns that he has been fed lies but his ego doesn't let him accept his mistake, and he lets the wedding take place. Chanda (Kalki Koechlin) has been caught up in a sex scandal. Her father commits suicide and after being disowned by her family, becomes a woman of ill repute. When Dev's path crosses hers, they realise they are both disillusioned souls destined to be with each other. All the films being shown at the Festival are recent award winning films selected from Panorama of Indian Cinema and are drawn from different regions and languages of India (all sub-titled in English) depicting the diversities of Indian culture and society. These are all award winning movies from 2007 to 2009. Indian High Commissioner Malay Mishra said the Festival aimed to show the population of Trinidad and Tobago that films which are made in regional languages also form part of Indian cinema. He had stressed that Indian cinema is not Bollywood and that Indian cinema was far bigger than Bollywood. The Indian film industry is the biggest in the world, with 1,200 movies coming out of the country last year alone. Bollywood's contribution to this figure was just 200. High Commissioner Mishra said he hoped the week- long festival would open the door to many other opportunities including film student exchange programmes between the two countries. Parliamentary secretary in the Ministry of Arts and Multiculturalism, Nela Khan, said that film is one of the most natural ways to record and document a country's development and its culture. \"Culture and art provide an ideal vehicle for tightening the bonds between countries and, as a way to reach out, beyond governments and institutions, to the people. Through film we can enjoy and learn about different peoples of the world as well as their cultural diversity.\" She added that the importance of the Indian Film Festival cannot be underestimated in light of the development of Indian music and culture in this country. Khan said both countries, India and Trinidad and Tobago, have had a long relationship. \"In fact since 1845 when the first Indian indentured immigrant travelled from the continent in the Fatel Razack to our shores here in Trinidad and Tobago. From these very early years, music and culture have provided a life-line for our people to connect with their ancient heritage and to get a sense of comfort in this distant land. \"This fascination with India through the films,\" she said, \"has led to greater ties and a deeper relationship between our two countries. One of the benefits to this relationship has been the provision of scholarships to our nationals to pursue studies in Hindi and music at various institutes and universities throughout India.\" With the establishment of the Mahatma Gandhi Institute for Cultural Cooperation she said there was no longer a need for nationals to go to India since personalised tuition in the music and arts was now available for one and all. The Festival ends on November 23.
