{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/superblue-i-didnt-mash-up-soca-art-form/article_efa4ae74-6aed-51a1-916a-74d42e32bfc1.html", "TITLE": " SuperBlue: I didnt mash up soca art form ", "DATE": "Apr 19, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "In charge: Mavis John sings during Saturday\u0092s third instalment of the Women in Jazz 2014 series at MovieTowne, Invaders Bay, Port of Spain. The event was dedicated to Billie Holiday, aka \u0093Lady Day\u0094, the American jazz singer/songwriter who had a seminal influence on jazz and pop singing. From Holiday\u0092s repertoire, John sang \u0093God Bless The Child\u0094 and \u0093Strange Fruit\u0094. In addition, she sang a number of her own hits and songs of other local singers. \u0097Photo: GARY CARDINEZ In charge: Mavis John sings during Saturday\u0092s third instalment of the Women in Jazz 2014 series at MovieTowne, Invaders Bay, Port of Spain. The event was dedicated to Billie Holiday, aka \u0093Lady Day\u0094, the American jazz singer/songwriter who had a seminal influence on jazz and pop singing. From Holiday\u0092s repertoire, John sang \u0093God Bless The Child\u0094 and \u0093Strange Fruit\u0094. In addition, she sang a number of her own hits and songs of other local singers. \u0097Photo: GARY CARDINEZ Stating that he knew fellow calypsonians, soca artistes and others had said he mashed up the soca art form with his creation of the wave phenomenon when he sang, Get Something And Wave in 1991, SuperBlue defended his music. The reigning International Power Soca Monarch and National Road March champion was speaking during the launch of his new song, Borough Day, at the offices of Software Technologies Ltd, St James, on Thursday. I dont talk much, but share my thoughts through music. My focus is soca music for the rest of the world, to inform, educate and entertain. Trinidad has been good to me and, as a calypsonian, I inherited a platform from Cypher, Atilla, Sparrow and am thankful. People say I mash-up the art form with the wave thing, but I know it can stand up. Its all about ideas and not only all about wining and gyrating, SuperBlue said. He said Trinidad and Tobago Carnival is the only one of its kind and not even the carnivals that have been styled after ours are truly like Carnival here. He also said Carnival, calypso, soca and pan can be used to combat crime if only the proper resources would be invested into them by the authorities. We have given the word carnival a whole new meaning. To us it is a verb, a noun, an adjective. All the other carnivals are governed by a parade, they start at point A and end at Point B. Trinidad is different. We have freedom. Trinidad Carnival is a festival of food, of colour, of rhythm, of culture and I can go on and on. Every sickness has a cure and it maybe will not be in my time or your time, but there are answers for everything and calypso and soca can cure crime. The pan is also important and I would love to see 150 pannists playing Rebecca on the road one day. Forget about the 100 players limit, SuperBlue said. As for the song, Borough Day, it was recorded as a tribute to the Borough of Point Fortin where SuperBlue is from. It is also the theme song for Point Fortins Borough Day celebrations, which culminate on the weekend of May 3-5 and is in turn in tribute to SuperBlue this year. The song was composed by SuperBlue and Len Boogsie Sharpe, while Juelio Nelson did the production. SuperBlue said this is only the first follow-up to Road March winner Fantastic Friday and his plan is to release soca singles throughout the year, with the next to come being School Reunion Party. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/celebrating-the-diversity-of-trinbagonian-art/article_bec825ea-5f56-5627-8609-436d83eca541.html", "TITLE": " Celebrating the diversity of TRINBAGONIAN art ", "DATE": "Mar 23, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "\u0091AIRCRAFT SYSTEMS VERY RELIABLE\u0092: Director General of T&T Civil Aviation Authority Ramesh Lutchmedial \u0091AIRCRAFT SYSTEMS VERY RELIABLE\u0092: Director General of T&T Civil Aviation Authority Ramesh Lutchmedial The mysterious painting lures you. The more you scrutinise it, the more its solitude and loneliness suck you in like a magnet. It's a young girl. Her back is turned. She wears a black and white striped dress. She appears to be heading into nothingness; hair unkempt. Something is obviously wrong. Who is she What is her story There is much to be said about this amazing contemporary piece of artwork. The painting hangs at the entrance to the residence of the United States of America Chief of Mission, Flagstaff Hill, St James. It is one of eight selected works of local artists which aficionado of contemporary art, Charge d'Affaires, Thomas Smitham, personally selected. The painting is titled \"A Girl In a Stripe Dress\" by Sarah Knights. It is a 36\" x 48\" acrylic on canvas which incorporates other materials newsprint, a button and thread. An exhibit of some of the best contemporary artists on the island is being featured at the residence of the Chief of Mission with the theme \"Connecting Cultures: Connecting Art from Trinidad and Tobago\". It is aimed at unveiling the diversity of Trinidad and Tobago's contemporary art culture and linking cultures. It is an exhibition in conjunction with Medulla Gallery. Instead of sourcing the more popular aesthetics of Trinidad and Tobago's seascapes and landscapes, Smitham favoured contemporary artists whose works range in diverse themes. The selection of works by Wendy Nanan, Edward Bowen, Dean Arlen, Christopher Cozier, Irenee Shaw, Sarah Knights, Abigail Hadeed and Merylle Mahabir are all favoured by Smitham. Smitham told the Trinidad Express that while the works were distinctly Trinbagonian, they could also relate to anywhere else in the world. \"Art is a rich and universal language,\" Smitham said, \"one that, while grounded in some very specific cultural meanings also expresses the values, concerns and aspirations of our common humanity. \"I am finding that a lot of people don't know what is available here and how good your artists are. We are honoured to be able to get some of these fantastic works of artists in T&T and I hope it's not just for us but other people will also understand the existing diversity available here. We were much more interested about what the contemporary artists were producing. Traditional landscapes and seascapes are nice but the contemporary art reflects my personal interest. \"We felt it might be nice to feature the works of artists from Trinidad and Tobago in the residence. Through partnership with Medulla Gallery we were able to find some of the best artworks by some of the best contemporary artists from Trinidad and Tobago. What we have selected are representative of the diversity of Trinidad and Tobago and we wanted to display that. I am happy with what I have on the walls. The art works are all conversation starters for anyone who comes to the house because of the diverse range of themes from Trinidad and Tobago society and culture. \"When I came here the walls were empty and it took me a couple months to try to figure out what to do. We partnered with Medulla Art and instead of spending months of trying to find good art in the United States we decided to find what is available here instead. Having the art at the residence is a way for people to get familiar with the artists in Trinidad and Tobago. I found the extraordinary breadth of artistic expression, from music to art. For such a small island we have so many great artists so I thought it would be good to do an exhibit of these works here,\" Smitham said. Smitham will host a reception in honour of an exhibition of contemporary art from Trinidad and Tobago \"Connecting Cultures: Connecting Art from Trinidad and Tobago\" on April 3, 2013 at the residence of the US Chief of Mission, Flagstaff Hill, St James. There will be entertainment from US jazz musicians Master Gunnery Sergeant Robert Boguslaw, Gunnery Sergeamt Eric Sabo and Jeffrey Wills, who will perform a set of contemporary jazz for this occasion. Boguslaw and Sabo are members of President Obama's own US Marine Band. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/carnival/news/t-t-still-great-for-tourists/article_a4daccc6-1ea7-11e9-a39d-e784abea050d.html", "TITLE": " T&T still great for tourists ", "DATE": "Jan 22, 2019 ", "CONTENT": "Soca sensation: Nailah Blackman is scheduled to appear at Hilton\u2019s all-inclusive event, Lavish. {{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. Soca sensation: Nailah Blackman is scheduled to appear at Hilton\u2019s all-inclusive event, Lavish. Despite negative international reports, Trinidad and Tobago is still a great tourism destination, says Hilton Trinidad and Conference Centre general manager Olivier Maumaire. \u201cI must say what I heard about Trinidad before coming here was not that nice, which is unfortunate. I didn\u2019t really know what to expect before coming here, but I must say since I\u2019m here, it\u2019s really a great island,\u201d Maumaire told the Express on Friday, at the launch of Hilton\u2019s Carnival all-inclusive, Lavish. The well-travelled France-born hotelier said he counts these twin islands among the most culturally aware destinations he has ever visited. The former Hilton Jamaica and Aruba GM says his mission is to showcase that culture to international guests. \u201cIt is probably the most culture (aware) islands I\u2019ve ever been. In terms of food, the entertainment, the people, it\u2019s really very rich. There are many things to discover and I\u2019m very impressed by that. I think we have a duty to promote the island to the people outside and our guests travelling from all places of the world because often, they come for work and their only experience of Trinidad is the hotel. So we don\u2019t want to be like a bland hotel with nothing to offer. That\u2019s why for me, our mission is to show Trinidad to our clients and guests,\u201d he said. Local entertainment, food back on the menu In keeping with that objective, Maumaire\u2019s first order of business is to bring the excitement of Carnival back to the hotel. Under his leadership, Hilton has decided to restart their annual all-inclusive fete after a decade of inactivity, with the now rebranded Lavish. The hotel\u2019s boss promises the event will live up to all the connotations of its name and provide the perfect springboard for the global centennial celebration of the Hilton chain. \u201cI\u2019ve been to many carnivals in the world, right, but I think this one is really, really particular because you feel the essence of a culture. People participate, it\u2019s not just a show (you sit and watch). I was very impressed (last year) going to fetes and (seeing) how people behave and enjoy without getting into fights or whatever. \u201cFor me, it\u2019s a little like Christmas season in other countries where, all of a sudden, people become nice. Carnival here is like that. People are on another mood, everyone is happy and nobody sleeps, but that\u2019s another story,\u201d he said. The return to the fete circuit is just one of the changes Maumaire has brought to the Hilton. He has also spearheaded a rejuvenation of both the entertainment and food menus at the 57-year-old hotel. The hotel has remodelled its swimming pool and restaurant, and will now feature weekly art and music showcases, he said. \u201cTrinidad culture has to do with food, with art and with live entertainment. That\u2019s why we started Art at the Hilton because we have a big legacy of art here, having the second lar\u00adgest collection of local art on the island. We will have much more live music from local artistes as well. And all our menus are being revamped by the chef to include some of the flavours of the island,\u201d he concluded. During both tours, she collaborated with Reggae singer Kirk Brown, and artiste Ku-J, while also conducting a series of workshops at schools and non-profit organisations to inspire the youth. She also interviewed local business owners, brands and the towns people for her reality TV series, Diva TV which broadcast in five million homes in California, USA. Speaking to the youth and inspiring them to become confident individuals is what she calls The Diva Project. She loves to empower the youth and relate her previous living situation with theirs and being able to have a mutual understanding by Q&As from those who need someone influential to talk with. Conducting interviews of the natives and taping her journey through various activities in the country is what her reality show Diva TV contributes. In California she broadcasts her life as a female rapper in the Hip Hop industry and other Keldamuzik related events. There are more upcoming events featuring Diva in Grenada, Jamaica, Liberia, London, Puerto Rico, Germany, Trinidad and more! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/heritage-festival-launched/article_d1cbf81c-e2df-5414-8b22-d89a75f7cd1a.html", "TITLE": " Heritage Festival launched ", "DATE": "May 30, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "The annual Tobago Heritage Festival 2014 was launched Thursday with a street parade from Tambrin Square to the Scarborough Esplanade. This years theme is Community Treasures: Revelations. Chairman of the Tobago Heritage Festival Committee Wendell Berkley said special projects have been added to bring communities closer together. The festival runs from July 17 to August. This year we are focusing on the unity part of community where we are trying to ensure that all communities exist together and work together, culturally and otherwise. And as yesterday Indian Arrival Day was celebrated, the inclusion of religious bodies in the festival is of paramount importance, Culture Secretary Dr Denise Tsoiafatt-Angus said. The journey to heritage 2014 has unearthed relationships with various religious bodies, as we collaborate with them in their expression of their unique heritage, that has contributed to our Tobagoness, she added. She also said it was imperative to strengthen the heritage festival, to serve as an educative component, authentic learning, yet providing an entertaining environment for students. I charge you all with spreading the word that the heritage festival is not a performance but an interactive classroom for learning about ourselves, our shared history and the arts. In 2013, we reacquainted ourselves with our community treasures by digging deep into our past, exploring our heritage and unearthing the rites and rituals that make our cultural expressions and ultimately, our heritage unique, she said. 2014 will see a two-week festival that now includes the inaugural launch of a three-day workshop called CACI Conference on the Arts and Creative Industry. Tsoiafatt-Angus said this forum was critical for engaging multiple sectors in discussions on the effective ways to preserve and promote Tobagos rich culture. Such that we ensure our social development and resilience, what we know as the Tobago spirit will be intact throughout future generations. The 2014 production will reveal the stories, folk tales and songs, customs and traditions that were forgotten. The PVAF is defined by its directors as a hub for creative expression. It is their aim that the foundation will be the medium to bridge the gap between time and space; for such is the technological age that we live in. They serve as a promotional and events-based organisation dedicated to creating a platform/forums for all artistes; highlighting local artisans in poetry, spoken word, visual art, photography, music and the arts in general. The PVAF is also engaged in networking and partnering with artistes and artists locally and also worldwide to build strong alliances and to foster growth in the cultural and artistic arena. They also seek to act as agents for amateur and skilled artisans by facilitating the process for global opportunities through representation and promotion. It is also their aim to raise the level of public awareness and entertainment by supporting positive and creative expression. The PVAF was founded by Rachael Collymore a photographer/writer/poet with a passion for all aspects of culture, entertainment and the arts and their respective development. She wanted to positively contribute to the local creative sector and entertainment industry by producing arts-based events and showcasing young and upcoming artistes along with the more accompished entertainers. I started Poetic Vibes some years ago because I had a passion for writing and poetry and wanted to create a space for others with similar interests to share and express themselves I created a Facebook group in 2007 and Poetic Vibes was born. I met and connected with many talented people across the globe using this medium and it sparked a desire in me to do something more. I believe that the greatest resource any society can have is its culture and creativity, Collymore stated. The Synergia series was launched in 2010 and has been steadily building in quality and popularity since. The series has served as the platform from which several young artistes have begun their own careers in earnest. Part of the proceeds from the PVAT events go to the continued development of the artistes themselves. Among the artistes being featured at todays show is Cyrilia Lopez, a young singer and composer from Penal who cut her teeth doing gospel before deciding to expand her repertoire to other expressions. Her songs, however, maintain positivity and offer life-building ideals. This very talented young woman who has worked at a gas station along with other jobs is now focused on making it on the international arena and based on her vocals, songwriting prowess and performance style is not too far away from realising her dreams. Also on the lineup is the winner of the 2014 Bocas Lit Fest Verses Bocas Slam competition, Idrees Saleem who is a gifted poet and blossoming actor from Arouca. The event also features performances by Afiya Ayanna Athill, Jessie Mc Barrow and visual, Annelie Solis. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/tuco-boss-calls-for-more-venues/article_4ce51192-06f5-5b1b-83b1-a4fc1dfcae79.html", "TITLE": " TUCO boss calls for more venues ", "DATE": "Aug 9, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "URGENT MATTER: Brother Resistance URGENT MATTER: Brother Resistance Brother Resistance (Lutalo Masimba), president of Trinbago Unified Calypsonians Organisation (TUCO), has said the closure of the National Academy for the Performing Arts (NAPA) emphasised the need for more venues for cultural shows. He also said TUCO was affected since the organisation had events for Calypso History Month in October. Calypso History Month is billed as a celebration that focuses on the impact of calypso on peoples lives while celebrating the contribution of pioneers like the late Aldwyn Roberts (Lord Kitchener) and developing an appreciation for the indigenous art form. Brother Resistance, said: TUCO had a number of shows scheduled for NAPA and it would be affected by any closure of the facility. It also underlines the crisis that we have found ourselves in arts and entertainment which is a paucity of venues. We suffer greatly from the lack of venues. After 52 years of Independence, this dearth of venues should be addressed as a national priority. Making reference to Calypso History Month, Masimba added: TUCO had a number of shows and bookings inside for NAPA. Calypso History Month was scheduled to come off in October. As expected, we would have had a number of shows which would be a precursor to Carnival 2015. We would have to utilise the venue for a number of productions. Asked how he felt the situation should be addressed, Masimba said: I think the Government needs to view NAPAs closure as a matter of urgent national priority. There are a lot of technical problems. There are some challenges. I will not venture how the Government should go about it. They need to address it with urgency. Asked what he felt Finance Minister Larry Howai should allocate in the Budget for culture, Masimba said: There is the need for a better location for the Carnival organisations. It is mandatory for the special interest groups to deliver a better product. People expect us to deliver a great Carnival product. We are also looking forward to obtaining a broadcast licence for TUCO. Chairman of the TUCO South Zone Ras Kommanda (Steve Pascall) said: It is sad for the art form (calypso) and for the entire cultural fraternity. It is an indictment on the original contractors. Maybe, they should not have used the Chinese. Maybe, the local contractors should have been the ones to build it. Ras Kommanda added: Dont blame the government because they expected the best from the people who were awarded the contract. I know it is a blow to Calypso History Month. Out of evil cometh good, because they will have to move South for entertainment. In all seriousness, it does not augur well. Several young ladies will tonight compete in the finals of the NCIC (National Council of Indian Culture) Queen Pageant finals at the Divali Nagar, Chaguanas. As the activities wind down at the Nagar, which opened last week Sunday, visitors will tonight also enjoy a number of cultural performances along with the pageant. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/sparrow-collects-m-for-memorabilia/article_63b8118b-382e-5c95-9bc3-52243a030991.html", "TITLE": " Sparrow collects $2m for memorabilia ", "DATE": "Mar 17, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "{{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. Calypso icon The Mighty Sparrow (Slinger Francisco) received a payment of $2 million from the Ministry of Community Development, Culture and the Arts yesterday in exchange for a ten-year licence of the collection of his memorabilia. Sparrow, 80, wore a broad smile as he received his cheque at a signing-over ceremony at Queen's Hall in St Ann's. The legal procedure to acquire the mementos started in 2014. Sparrow didn't make a speech but instead chose to sing a line of song that expressed his feelings after receiving the cheque. \u201cIt's been a long time coming, it's been a long time coming but I know it was going to come.\u201d Sparrow, who also sang a few verses of a couple of old favourites, later told reporters he plans to use part of the money to refurbish his Petit Valley home, Sparrow's Hideaway. \u201cThe Hideaway has been there for a while...there are some repairs that need to be done so I must do that,\u201d he said. Sparrow said it feels good to have his personal collection on exhibit. \u201cI feel good...long time I used to drive about showing it, now people would have an opportunity to see them,\u201d he said. Long overdue Culture Minister Nyan Gadsby-Dolly said the payment had been long overdue. \u201cSparrow had been waiting a while for this to come to fruition and we wanted to be sure, given the urgency of time, that he would be able to be here to enjoy the payment. It had been an ongoing process with the previous administration and it had been overdue,\u201d said the minister. Gadsby-Dolly said the cheque presentation is a demonstration of the Government's belief that showcasing presentation and development of art and culture are essential to human development. \u201cThe work of our cultural icons, such as the Mighty Sparrow, has mirrored the everyday lives of Caribbean people. \u201cTheir compositions and presentations are not just opportunities for entertainment, but have also been a record of the experiences of our people and our history and, most importantly, has influenced our decision and our perceptions of ourselves. \u201cThe classic piece 'Education' comes to mind, which was an impassioned plea to persons at all levels of society to focus on the education of our children for the benefit of future generations and that type of contribution is so relevant, even today. \u201cThis collection of treasures, artefacts and memorabilia from the Mighty Sparrow gives the public a rare insight into the icon who has been our orator and our champion and has been bold enough to tell the wide range of our stories. \u201cIn a time when entertainers are becoming mere brands who are crafted in conference rooms, the Mighty Sparrow remains an authentic calypsonian,\u201d said Gadsby-Dolly. Candice Alcantara, head of corporate communications at the Ministry of Community Development, Culture and the Arts, described Sparrow's work as a timeless record of the responses to the socio-economic changes and challenges faced by the people of Trinidad and Tobago and the Caribbean. 'Jean and Dinah' The National Theatre Arts Company of Trinidad and Tobago gave an entertaining and creative presentations of Sparrow's calypsoes, including \u201cMelda\u201d, \u201cMae Mae\u201d, \u201cDoh Back Back\u201d, \u201cDrunk and Disorderly\u201d and \u201cJean and Dinah'. The memorabilia, spanning Sparrow's 60-year career, will be showcased in an exhibition titled \u201cTreasures from the Hideaway\u201d, at the Division of Culture, second floor of the Jobco Building, Frederick Street, Port of Spain. On display will be pictures, CDs, certificates, crowns, medals, plaques and videos. The exhibition is free to the public. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/remembering-ma-boots/article_5e222776-8c51-5c42-943b-c9cd80748402.html", "TITLE": " Remembering Ma Boots ", "DATE": "Oct 13, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "The following is the eulogy read by musician/artist David Boothman at the funeral of his mother Marjorie Holder Boothman on October 4, which took place at the Holy Trinity Cathedral, which happened to be her birthdate. Boothman was the sister of two famous artists Boscoe and Geoffrey Holder. Her sons Micheal, David and Roger are well-known in the world of music and art. In our photo she is accompanied by her famous sister-in-law Carmen de Lavellade wife of Geoffrey Holder. The photo was taken at the Icons of T&T Award Ceremony in May 2013 at which de Lavellade collected an award on behalf of Geoffrey. Our Mother Marjorie Holder Boothman has passed. She was one of the most incredible, intelligent, being charitable I know. She was the mother of an over, over, over-extended family of family, friends, artists, musicians, writers and community from her own contemporary through my siblings and their children. This community ranged throughout four generations. Although I am second in the line of my siblings, I am lost in the position of this over, over, over extended family. She was a leader and fighter for various causes related to arts and culture and heritage. She was a social worker that fought with the group Friends of the Hospital for changes and funding for PoS General Hospital. She was a historian, storyteller a cultural guardian a true griot . Ma Boots had an acute and extraordinary memory, she had a special gift. She could remind an elephant. Those who knew her would attest to that. Historians from all over the world would come to interview her on Caribbean culture and families. She gave freely to anyone in proximity. With that, there was a fiery passion, articulation, sincerity that would lambaste, inform, inspire and entertain all in love in her Libran way weighing the scales of justice. She celebrated her birthday on October 4th. She never went to collegenever had to. She was college. She kept all my college books and up to this day in her library and from time to time would keep me updated. She opened our home to everyone, to local and foreign artists. My mother and father started a foundation called Seeds of Talent. A concept celebrating families in the arts. They created events propelling this wonderful concept up to a time when life became harder, funding and interest questionable when corporate and government invested in more cultural trivia Ya cyan cast pearl before swinenow today even swine saying that What a dilemma. She was concerned about media programming as she cared about the conditioning of the youths minds. Ceos and ministers square pegging round holes. She had touched all three months before Lord Shorty s passing, I met with him and his wife in St James, he told me yuh know Booty, your mother and yuh family inspired me on my journey with my family. It was a great feeling to hear that and this traction was and still is evident in stories coming out of the woodwork from long time friends and artists. Another wisdom saying was Making art is about making art making money is about making moneytwo separate operationskeep them separate. My mother had inspired me twenty years ago to start the work of the Caribbean Cultural Icons Collection before it was ever conceived in the cultural ministries or media as an idea or interest. In it, I had included Umilta McShine, Roaring Lion, Pat Castangne, and a range of our multi-cultural icons who have contributed so much to the Caribbean culture. Now she is included in the collection. She also reminded that our culture is more than the Eurocentric, Afrocentric, Indo-centric, Asian-centric, it is also more Caribbean-centric. The racially political divide is a wearing adversarial device that is counter productive to our innate potential and growth in the Caribbean. Today one can see why there is no leadership with content. There is no room for Arawak, no room for the divine, no room for quality everyone only assessing by quantity. She was a fighter to the end even when the angel of death came ...had to convince her that her work is completed and the culture is too hardened and needed a different energy to continue the workShe did let go with the assurance that her work was not in vain. She is the last of a generation of cultural matriarchs She was backbone of a wonderful over, over, over, over extended family. To all within proximity of understanding: I know at this time the passing of our mom, The T&Ts Cultural Matriarch brings us to the cross-road of lifes meaning again. In this great initiation, we know at this time there is a power we have to grasp that is for us. In every passing of a family member leaves that luminous power that makes us stronger and attuned to the spirit world. It is for us to carry on the work and the blessing as we share in this temporary side of life. Lets seek this power and smile knowing the everlasting connection of the other world of Gods light and love. We all are from the greatest families on the planet. I would like share this poem with you which shows that nothing is in vain and every life returns to its origin of light. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/reviving-fun-and-creativity/article_b517e828-a7a7-55e8-bf18-e2907add15d7.html", "TITLE": " Reviving fun and creativity ", "DATE": "Jun 27, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "This is one of the missions of Dr Dave Alleyne, Bishop of the Flaming Word Cathedral and Head of the Human and Social Development Committee, a sub-committee of the Chaguanas Local Economic Development (LED) Steering Committee, established by the Ministry of Planning and Sustainable Development through the Economic Development Board, responsible for transforming the Borough of Chaguanas to City status, as he hosted a costume party in Chaguanas.The costume party attracted quite a number of patrons as they paraded their costumes portraying different characters such as Wolverine, Superman, Rocky Balboa, Shrek, Maleficent, Blade, Egyptian and Greek goddesses, captains, sailors and so many others. The event also featured local heartthrob General Imran and jazz band Fred and the Graduates. Fred Absalom a professional jazz musician /saxophonist who attended Julliard Classical School of Music and worked in the Jazz Mobile Summer Programme in New York provided a rich, diverse blend of jazz music while DJ Chubrock of DM Soundz Company (Darryl and Darren Manick) kept patrons on their feet way into the night until early morning light. In his welcome remarks Alleyne stated that entertainment is one of the pillars on which a society is built. The higher the level of entertainment, the greater the society will become among other pillars. This was echoed in keeping with his mandate to see the development of a creative hub in Chaguanas, as he presses for the proposed city to become a modern world class metropolis that can attract people from all over the globe with its multiplicity of culture. One of the four areas that the Human and Social Development Committee seeks to develop in Chaguanas is culture and creative and performing arts. Alleyne believes that economic development can be enhanced by encouraging and facilitating creativity and human capital. He believes that by bringing firms, artistes, and cultural facilities together, a multiplier effect can result that would create great wealth and sustainable development.The peoples choice for best costume (male and female) was awarded to Angelo Woodley who portrayed Shrek and Fareeaa Karmali who designed and created her own costume Maleficent. There will be booths highlighting Tassa drums and Chutney music from their early origins to today. This year, the Village will introduce a Junior calypso tent, co-hosted by Trinbago Unified Calypsonians Organisation (TUCO). There will be lots of indigenous food and drink on sale, and nightly entertainment including calypso, stick fighting, minstrels and speech bands. On February 25,there will be a Chutney competition for primary and secondary schools. The Carnival Institute will display costumes and photos on the origins and development of Carnival, and a Carnival Art Exhibition, co-hosted by the Art Society of Trinidad and Tobago which will show work from local artists on the theme of mas. There will also be a wide range of craft, clothing and jewelry available. Several government ministries will also participate, The Village will feature presentations for school children between 8 a.m. and 3 p.m., with evening entertainment from 5 p.m. to 11 p.m. Admission is free and a 24-hour security will be provided. The launch will feature soca and calypso performers including Mr Famous, SuperBlue, Bro. Superior and band, Oscar B and band, K.I. and Triveni, and Shurwayne Winchester and YOU. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ncic-head-calls-for-name-change/article_a6e34ee1-f976-5dd2-94bb-fb872438b50a.html", "TITLE": " NCIC head calls for name change ", "DATE": "Jul 19, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "HONOURED: Awardees at Saturday\u0092s National Council of Indian Culture (NCIC) 50th anniversary celebrations at the Divali Nagar site, Chaguanas. Standing from left are Hans Hanoomansingh, Bob Ramroop, Deokienanan Sharma, Krishendath Joe Ramkissoon, Richard Ramlakhansingh and Ralph Narine. Seated is Baldeo Maharaj. \u0097Photos: Sandhya Santoo HONOURED: Awardees at Saturday\u0092s National Council of Indian Culture (NCIC) 50th anniversary celebrations at the Divali Nagar site, Chaguanas. Standing from left are Hans Hanoomansingh, Bob Ramroop, Deokienanan Sharma, Krishendath Joe Ramkissoon, Richard Ramlakhansingh and Ralph Narine. Seated is Baldeo Maharaj. \u0097Photos: Sandhya Santoo As he pleaded for State assistance to transform the Divali Nagar in Chaguanas into a heritage site, National Council of Indian Culture (NCIC) president Dr Deokienanan Sharma declared that the site should be named the NCIC Nagar. Sharma said the NCIC, which is housed at the site, intends to expand the facility and include a library and research centre. He said a peace and spiritual park would also be constructed to enhance the site. He said the NCIC had made significant contributions to the development of Indian culture in Trinidad and Tobago. I declare today this site, which has not yet been named, which has been known as Divali Nagar site, will henceforth be officially called NCIC Nagar, said Sharma. And he denied rumours that the Divali Nagar was being funded by the State. Sharma maintained that the NCIC continues to raise funds through fund-raisers, donations and rental of the site by the Indian Trade Fair. Sharma was speaking at the NCIC 50th anniversary ceremony at the Divali Nagar site on Saturday night. Seven founding members and persons who have contributed to the development of the organisation were honoured at the function. Former NCIC president Hans Hanoomansingh was among those honoured for outstanding contributions to the promotion and preservation of Indian culture in Trinidad and Tobago. The others were retired Justice Ralph Narine, Baldeo Maharaj, Bob Ramroop, Richard Ramlakhansingh, Krishendath Joe Ramkissoon and Sharma. Minister of Trade, Industry, Investment and Communications Vasant Bharat attended the function and brought greetings on behalf of Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar. He praised NCIC for its work over the years and for supporting Indian culture. He said the NCIC was a positive impact on Trinidad and Tobago. Bharath pledged his support to the organisation through his Ministry and said he would support a televised documentary on the lives of the seven icons. The organisation was established by founding members Bisram Gopie and Narsaloo Ramaya at a time when East Indian art forms depended on oral traditions. It was formed to promote the preservation of Indian culture and to expose the younger generations to their cultural roots, he said. NCIC continues to make contributions through cultural programmes, publication of books, magazines and newsletters and art exhibitions. NCIC hosted book fairs and international cricket matches between the West Indies and India for its 150th Indian Arrival Day Anniversary. The organisation has received 16 awards and honorary doctoral degrees were bestowed upon two of its executivesHanoomansingh and Sharmafrom The University of the West Indies. NCIC has also promoted and trained singers, dancers and musicians through scholarships and volunteer work. The NCIC hosted the first International Diaspora Conference, with speakers from around the world presenting research papers on the Indo-Caribbean Diasporic Culture, based on historical and future context of the Indian culture. Entertainment at the anniversary celebrations was provided by Narendra Maharaj, Vijay Ramkissoon and group, Rawle Motilal, and the bmobile Shiv Shakti Dance Company. YOUNGEST HONOUREE: Deputy Mayor Keron Valentine presents Kleah Mannette with her award. Eighteen-year-old Kleah Mannette created history on Friday evening by being the youngest honouree of the St James Community Improvement Committee (CIC). The committee broke with their tradition of honouring retired persons who have served the community. The audience at the launch of the 14th edition of WeBeat at the St James Amphitheatre was made up of most of the past honourees who were very pleased with the CICs choice this year. Mannette won the Dr Leroy Clarke Trophy for the Most Outstanding in the Women in Art Competition and followed that by winning the Republic Bank Trophy for Graphics for Cooperative Use. In the CXC examinations, Mannette placed ninth in the Caribbean in Art and earned distinctions in three categories. An avid pannist, she is currently on PCS Silver Stars stage side and is also studying for her Level Five Certificate in music. She says art is music and the same way a story can be told through a song, it parallels what could be done with a painting. The other honouree on Friday evening was actor/playwright/teacher/cultural ambassador Freddie Kissoon. The 83-year-old founder of the Strolling Players has a long history in the arts and entertainment industry, having written over 70 plays and acted on stage over 200 times. He is specially noted for his classic local play Calabash Alley. Kissoon has received several awards internationally and locally, among these is the distinguished Humming Bird Medal for his contribution to Culture-Drama and Theatre. Also attending the honourees award presentation were Minister of Justice Emmanuel George, Deputy Mayor of Port of Spain Keron Valentine and Joan Yullie-Williams. Deputy Mayor Valentine officially opened WeBeat and helped in the presentation of the awards. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/celebrating-years-of-the-naparima-bowl/article_da6bcdf7-88dc-5291-af85-a9fb0f5105a9.html", "TITLE": " Celebrating 50 years of the Naparima Bowl ", "DATE": "Aug 25, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "A GIFT FOR CAROLYN: San Fernando West MP Carolyn Seepersad-Bachan is greeted on arrival at the Naparima Bowl, San Fernando, by Sandra Sawak-Allum. A GIFT FOR CAROLYN: San Fernando West MP Carolyn Seepersad-Bachan is greeted on arrival at the Naparima Bowl, San Fernando, by Sandra Sawak-Allum. Stunning, historic and emotional, aptly described the 50th anniversary concert presented by southern cultural activists who over the past 50 years had performed in song, music, dance and drama at Naparima Bowl, San Fernando. The commemorative concert titled \"An era in an evening\" took place at the Bowl's auditorium on Saturday, with over 600 patrons attending the show. The production, which was conceptualised and directed by cultural activist James Lee Wah, told the story of Naparima Bowl during its 50 years of existence, giving samples of the artistic life of San Fernando, and also the ill- fated fire that destroyed part of the Bowl in 1977. Lee Wah remarked, \"We owe all of this to two great citizens of San Fernando, businessman Robert Montano and music teacher Grace Abdool who had the vision and determination to campaign for a theatre for San Fernando. The three-hour concert began with a forecourt welcome by Carnival masqueraders, African drummers, tassa drummers and a display by moko jumbies. Following this patrons were entertained by members of the Arawak Dance Group led by dance icon Torrance Mohammed to be followed by sensations in steel and Indian classical dances. In the field of drama, Ralph Maraj returned to his old performing ground accompanied by Mavis Lee Wah in Shakespeare's Dark Lady of the Sonnet, a George Bernard Shaw play. Joy Caesar was on hand to conduct the Southern Knights performance \"Valderi Valdera\", as well as the Southernaires Choir. The entire performance was to show those who were not around when the Bowl opened its doors in August 1962 that \"the Bowl brought life to the arts and it must remain as the cultural centre of the south\", Lee Wah said. Chairman of the Bowl's Management committee Sandra Sawak-Allum commented, \"I am proud to be able to say that after so many years the Bowl continues to grow stronger and stronger as the cultural receptacle of the south.\" Attending the performance was Carolyn Seepersad-Bachan, MP for San Fernando West and Minister of Public Administration. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/karma-scores-big-at-awards/article_ed0feaf4-af35-58ab-9c59-fc16b3d6b65e.html", "TITLE": " Karma Scores Big At Awards ", "DATE": "Nov 27, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " EXPRESSIVE: Members of the Nirvana dance group during one of their performances. EXPRESSIVE: Members of the Nirvana dance group during one of their performances. Karma and Hemlata Dindial scored big at the tenth 103FM Hall of Fame and Music Awards Ceremony at Queen's Hall, St Ann's in a night that paid tribute to the best in local Indian culture and heritage. Musical powerhouse Karma lifted the titles for Best Produced CD by a Local Band and Album of the Year for Karmageddon, whilst Ravi B bested the rest in the groups, Best Chutney Soca Collaboration (Jep Sting Remix featuring Hunter, Ravi B and Kees), Best Music Video (Dularie Tanty produced by Peter C Lewis, Synergy TV), Courts 'Trini Hit' Most Popular Local Song (Dularie Tanty) and bmobile's People's Choice (Dularie Tanty). A visibly overwhelmed Dindial earned the coveted Song of the Year award for Kaan \"Payra\". Dindial was also named Best Female Chutney Artiste and her tune also topped the category of Best Musical Arranger (Original Song). Kenneth Salick's \"Radica\", won the awards for Best Lyricist and Best Chutney Soca Song. The night also saw eight individuals and groups being inducted into the prestigious Hall of Fame. Video presentations on each inductee preceded the segment. This year the list included Sam Boodram (classical singing), Sandra Sookdeo (dance), Emanuel Doon, (folk art expressions), Doon Ramsundar (instrumentalist), the Naya Tarana Orchestra (orchestration), the Boodoosingh Tassa Group (tassa) and the Cedar Hill Youth Social and Cultural Organisation (folk expressionsRamleela). Special Family Recognition was given to the Jeewan Singh Family for their promotion of Indian culture. Special Recognition Awards were bestowed upon Justice Ralph Narine, Southex chief executive officer, George Singh and chief executive officer, Balroop's Sound Systems Limited, Vishnu Balroop. Performances throughout the night were done not by the artistes themselves but rising stars such as Hall of Fame inductee Doon Ramsundar, Satnarine Ragoo and young talents Sangeeta Subnaik, Pranava Maharaj and Avinash Maharaj. Entertainers were backed by the Nirvana Dancers. Music was provided by JMC 3Veni. The event was broadcast live on television and was attended by President George Maxwell Richards, Dr Jean Ramjohn-Richards and Arts and Multiculturalism Minister, Winston Peters. In opening the night's activities, 103FM Chairman Reyaz Ahamad said the event had come a long way from its humble beginnings in 2000 when it was first held at Centre Point Mall in Chaguanas. Then there were six inductees. He said that since then, 100 names have been inducted into the 103 Hall of Fame. The aim, he said, has always been the same: to recognise the efforts of those who develop, perpetuate and preserve East Indian culture. He said the show has given hope to cultural figures for their hard work over the years that has not been recognised or appreciated. He added that to the artistes, it represents the reward for their toil. \"Many look at these awards as a mark of appreciation of their art. They also strive more diligently because of it since such recognition provides a benchmark for further endeavours. In a wider cultural sphere, this ceremony serves to draw attention to the culture produced by the Indian diaspora. It has helped to define and develop the growing East Indian music industry. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/capital-in-step-with-the-times/article_489f2608-75f4-5f1f-998f-e309a2411063.html", "TITLE": " Capital in step with the times ", "DATE": "Oct 3, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "flashback: Dr Wayne Kublalsingh and supporters pray on Wednesday during his hunger strike outside the Office of the Prime Minister in St Clair. \u0097Photo: curtis chase flashback: Dr Wayne Kublalsingh and supporters pray on Wednesday during his hunger strike outside the Office of the Prime Minister in St Clair. \u0097Photo: curtis chase Steeped in its evocative history and the rapid changes that have taken place over the past two decades, Berlin today exerts its own particular fascination. Twenty years after the fall of the Berlin Wall and the reunification of Germany, the capital projects itself as a young, dynamic and cosmopolitan city at the heart of Europe. Originally a symbol of separation, since Reunification the former \"Walled City\" of Berlin has developed into a popular travel destination and is highly indicative of the current trend. Guests are not only interested in the history and culture of the city, but also in the way it has changed. But exactly what is it that actually makes Berlin so attractive It is the diversity, the contrasts and the sheer inexhaustible potential of this capital city to consistently fire the enthusiasm of its visitors from all over the world. The exciting mixture of history and Zeitgeist, the broad spectrum of art, culture, music, entertainment and shopping facilities, the modern hotel landscape, the diversity of its cuisine and its outstanding cost-effectiveness by comparison to other destinations in Europe all go to make up the special charm that is the metropolis on the Spree. A flourishing creative scene together with Berlin's hip music and club culture likewise contribute to the unmistakable lifestyle metropolis with a population of around 3.4 million. At the heart of Berlin's arts landscape is the Museum Island, encompassing five buildings in the historic city centre. When the Neues Museum was reopened in October 2009 it was the first time for 70 years that all the museums in the ensemble, unique in the world and a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1999, had been accessible to the public. As a UNESCO \"City of Design\" and the first German city to figure in the worldwide network of \"Creative Cities\", Berlin is well to the fore in the architecture, art and fashion sectors. It is here in the hip 'scene' metropolis that tomorrow's trends are born. Since Reunification the Berlin artistic scene has developed into one of the most exciting and dynamic in Europe and is currently experiencing an enormous influx of creative talent from all over the world. The number of galleries in which young, talented artists present contemporary and alternative art for the collections of tomorrow is increasing rapidly. Neither are the shopping facilities in Berlin any less varied than the fashions. It's all there - from chic to trendy, from elegant haute couture right through to casual urban and street wear. In the evenings a multitude of experiences awaits in the shape of the ever changing Berlin music and club scene where closing time is unheard of. With its pulsating nightlife and unusual locations, the party metropolis weaves a spell that captivates everyone. Berliners and international tourists can experience the sound of the capital in the hip bars and discotheques of the city, where you can dance and party right through to the small hours. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/rhythms-and-drums-in-st-james/article_8ad97dcd-be8d-5f13-a2a3-21a503108ab1.html", "TITLE": " Rhythms and drums in St James ", "DATE": "Mar 16, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "BEATS WITH PASSION: Nyron Greenidge and Jerry Achee are founding members of the Village Drums of Freedom from St James. The group has for the past 42 years produced an annual festival of culture shortly after Carnival. \u2013Photo: Stephen Doobay BEATS WITH PASSION: Nyron Greenidge and Jerry Achee are founding members of the Village Drums of Freedom from St James. The group has for the past 42 years produced an annual festival of culture shortly after Carnival. \u2013Photo: Stephen Doobay For 42 years a group of culture-lovers from St James have been sharing their passion for the drum with the people of the nation through their annual three-day event. The Village Drums of Freedom (VDF) will from today host their post Carnival production, Rhythms and Drums Around the World at the Ellie Mannette Park at the corner of DeFreitas and Alfred Richard Streets, St James. VDF founding member, Nyron Greenidge told the Express that today will feature a video night where clips of past productions will be shown. There will also be videos exploring African cultures, Afro-Trinbagonian culture and documentaries about various facets of the African continent. This event is free to the public as are the others over the weekend. Tomorrow the VDF hosts a Reggae Night show and dance from 10 p.m. that will include live performances by several local reggae singers, including, King David. Several top conscious sound systems such as Lion King, Black Chariot, Solid Rock and DJ Nardel will be among the systems providing music throughout the night. Sunday is the annual Childrens Treat where the little ones from the community and environs will be served snacks and be entertained through games and various activities from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. The Culture Fest will follow with performances by several calypsonians including, Valentino, Black Stalin, Blaxx, Gary Cordner, SuperBlue, Lavway and Crazy. Among the steel orchestras appearing are: Phase II Pan Groove, Scrunters Pan Groove, Tripolians and North Stars. The drum ensembles performing are: Block 4, Culture Shop, Northwest, St James Cultural Drummers and the Wassi Dance Company. There will also be a presentation on the International Year for People of African Descent, which is being observed this year. Other performances include moko jumbies and other traditional mas characters. Greenidge said over the years the VDF has received assistance from the Government from time to time in producing the event, but he said it is not sure if the Peoples Partnership will offer assistance. They continue to do the events of the festival out of pocket and with the assistance of businesses in the St James community as well as people that contribute what they can. Fellow VDF founding member, Jerry Achee added that the festival is a labour of love and a way to encourage the youth to pursue culture rather than crime. The VDF was formed by a group of pupils from the Mucurapo Boys RC Primary. The school was participating in the Schools Arts Festival of 1969 and had invited pupils to join the dance troupe. Some of the dancers lived in what was known as the Housing Scheme in St James and they were always liming and playing football and cricket. After the arts festival the group continued to perform under the name of Scheme Rangers. With no adult leader the seven youths saw after their own affairs and eventually attracted the attention of several elders in the area and as far away as Carenage that began to assist them by giving them advice. The group became well known and was invited to perform at various concerts and functions such as opening ceremonies of the St James Youth Centre as well as the Carenage and Maraval Community Centres. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-best-village-story/article_79842fde-ba0f-5276-bbe4-38276bbde39b.html", "TITLE": " The Best Village story ", "DATE": "Aug 30, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "T&T SPRINTERS: Richard \"Torpedo\" Thomson, left, from Trinidad and Tobago wins the men's 100 metres race at the ISTAF Athletics Meeting in Berlin, Germany, on Sunday. At right is third-placed Keston Bledman, also from T&T. Photo: AP T&T SPRINTERS: Richard \"Torpedo\" Thomson, left, from Trinidad and Tobago wins the men's 100 metres race at the ISTAF Athletics Meeting in Berlin, Germany, on Sunday. At right is third-placed Keston Bledman, also from T&T. Photo: AP Shortly after independence Prime Minister Dr Eric Williams embarked on a Meet the People Tour throughout the villages in Trinidad. At the end of the tour he described the exercise as an unforgettable experience that brought me in contact with the ordinary people. As the nations first Prime Minister he said, all that was needed was to give the energy and enthusiasm I found in the villages the opportunities for self expression and a home in which to nurture the arts, craft and other cultural expressions of our people. Arising out of the tour he announced a programme called The Prime Ministers Best Village Trophy Competition (PMBVTC). The aim of the programme was to accelerate building of community centres throughout the country, and using these centres to promote the latent talent in the villages. Although he had travelled extensively during election campaigns, he admitted that he had not visited some areas in Trinidad and Tobago, especially in the rural areas.Williams said, One of the valuable results of the tours was that I was able to know the country better than I did before. The report on his visit quoted him as saying, It was not my first visit to L Anse Fourmi or to Paratuvier. I already knew quite well La Fillette or Brasso Seco, which has always been one of my favourite spots of natural beauty of the countryside. But the tour allowed me to pay my first visit to Aripo a village way behind Gods back. All that I could say to the people of Trinidad is that living behind Gods back is beautiful. During the tour, Williams met with village council members, womens groups, youth groups, sporting and cultural clubs, and agricultural credit societies. Everywhere he went there were schoolchildren on hand to perform and entertain him. Inspired by this Williams went on, after the construction of community centres and other projects, to establish in earnest the Better Village programme under the direction of Joyce Wong Sang, his sister-in-law, and cultural activist Norvan Fullerton. Wong Sang in a recent interview said, when the programme started we had no prior knowledge of what form it should take. We started from scratch, we made some mistakes, but by and large it achieved the purpose set out by the Prime Minister. She explained that the vision of the PMBVTC was to champion the integrated village concept in and among communities throughout Trinidad and Tobago. It was also to partner with other communities to identify and satisfy their needs through the provision of gender sensitive, quality programmes and services. Wong Sang said, the objective of the programme was to empower communities, by providing them with opportunities that will enhance the surroundings in which they live. It was also designed to promote national pride, and to encourage folk art and the upliftment of art in general, as well as identifying historical and environmental sites throughout Trinidad and Tobago. After serving as Director of the Programme for 25 years she retired. In 1992 she was awarded the Chaconia Medal Gold. for her services in the area of cultural development. The competition started in January each year. Its aim was to build preserve and protect folk traditions and facilitate the growth of natural culture in categories of traditional Carnival, handicraft, food and folk fair, environmental sanitation and selection of a queen at a show called La Reine Rive. Prizes were awarded in each category with the overall winner receiving a $200,000 prize. La Reine Rive, a popular cultural presentation, is now the longest running queen competition in Trinidad and Tobago. It is open to females between the ages 16-25 years. Many contestants from the La Reine Rive queen competition went on to enter other queen competitions. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/an-indefatigable-dame-of-journalism/article_5163edda-9406-5d52-8018-1e52317e4e97.html", "TITLE": " An indefatigable dame of journalism ", "DATE": "Dec 4, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "\u201cAN indefatigable dame of journalism.\u201d Those were the words Newsday editor-in-chief Jones P Madeira used to sum up the late Anne Hilton's stellar career. Hilton, 87, died around 4 p.m. on Sunday at her Cascade home. She was born in England in 1929 and she and her late husband, John Hilton, lived in Jamaica and Colombia before they settled in Trinidad in 1965. During her extensive career, Hilton wrote for all three daily newspapers on the arts, health, environment, food and orchestral music. She won a dizzying number of awards, including several from the Pan American Health Organisation (PAHO). Interviewed yesterday, Madeira said: \u201cI am quite saddened. I am taken by surprise. She was a Newsday columnist and freelance journalist providing articles. Her passion for arts, culture, cuisine and entertainment drove her beyond the limits. \u201cAlthough she was well advanced, Hilton was eternally committed to her craft. She had a long, quality life. Her commitment to the noble profession of journalism is what one desires and the discipline with which she approached her task. It is a trait young professionals should emulate. \u201cAt one time, I was on the other side of the fence as head of the panel of judges that looked after adjudication. She produced outstanding pieces and she won a number of awards. I will truly miss her...an ever enthusiastic photojournalist, she took her pictures as well, particularly when one was part of the social circuit. She brought her photographs home with proper captions. Then she started getting frail. \u201cShe really did the profession proud. May she rest in peace,\u201d he added. Gadsby-Dolly: She has left a gap Also sharing her sentiments was Minister of Community Development, Culture and the Arts Dr Nyan Gadsby-Dolly, who said: \u201cI noted her critique of arts and artists. She had extensive knowledge about issues and she had a wide berth of interests and expertise. Her comments were taken seriously by the environmental and performing arts sector. \u201cIt's always a loss when one has lost a pillar in the society. One looks at the present landscape and hopes there will be someone who can fill her shoes. She has left a gap with her passing. I wish to extend condolences to her family and friends.\u201d Hilton will also be mourned by her daughter Penny and son Alexander and her three grandchildren. The first band mounted the stage around 3.30 p.m. under the blistering sun, only to return 20 minutes later to entertain Arts and Multiculturalism Minister Lincoln Douglas and a contingent of visiting Nigerian nationals. The Nigerian guests, said Minister Douglas, were in Trinidad to experience the festival and support it by exporting Trinidad and Tobago culture in Nigeria. However, when they arrived there was very little for them to see and the first band, Chaguanas RC School, portraying Fancy Sailors, was asked to return to the stage with their fancy foot and powder presentation. Douglas said they were visiting several other regional Carnival parades in Paramin and Arima. One hour later, the second band, Leslie-Ann Morgan and Associates, tried to recapture the guests' attention with their presentation, \"We Culture, We People\", but even then they seemed hardly amused. After the band had completed its presentation, Minister Douglas and his entourage joined them for a photograph off stage and they left the site. Patrons and masqueraders did not come out in their usual numbers as in previous years, leaving other guests without entertainment. Also present were Allison Demas, chairman of the National Carnival Commission (NCC), coordinator of Regional Carnival Ramchand Rajbal, Minister of Tertiary Education Fazal Karim and People's National Movement labour relations officer Jennifer Baptiste-Primus. Chairman of Carapichaima Carnival Committee Llewellyn McDonald said the committee was granted their proposed budget of $300,000 to host the event. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/what-s-our-carnival-policy/article_844062b3-cc97-5bdd-8da9-68861c5f3e4f.html", "TITLE": " what's Our Carnival Policy ", "DATE": "Feb 17, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Naparima spinner: Jovan Ali PANELIST: Dr Suzanne Burke Naparima spinner: Jovan Ali PANELIST: Dr Suzanne Burke with such a richly diverse cultural heritage one would think Trinidad and Tobago would have long ago established a State Policy for Culture and the Carnival Arts. That, however, is only now being set in place by the Peoples Partnership Government after years of pleading for such by people involved in the cultural as well as the arts and entertainment sectors. The Department of Creative & Festival Arts of the University of the West Indies on February 11 held the inaugural symposium of its Thnk Tank series at the Centre for Language Learning Auditorium UWI, St Augustine. The day's theme was; Carnival, Multiculturalism and State Policy and among the panelists were Peter Minshall, Dr Pat Bishop, Dr Suzanne Burke, Marcia Riley and Peter Scoon. One of the sessions in the daylong symposium was titled Carnival and Multiculturalism Development. Here the panel explored whether or not Carnival could be used as a catalyst for developing a National Cultural Policy that is underpinned by the concepts of diversity and social inclusion. Dr Bishop took the lead here, opening her presentation stating, \"I have nothing interesting to say,\" causing light laughter to erupt from the audience that consisted of players in the cultural and Carnival arenas. Bishop went on to say that everyone knows that when it comes to Carnival in Trinidad and Tobago the, \"French claim it. The Africans counterclaim it and the contemporary Carnival is not as creative as it was. The music is louder, faster and it is more intensely marketed.\" Bishop went on to say that today, in the midst of the continued commercialisation of Carnival we see panmen who are begging for more money to play in Panorama being shot and killed in \"the blood rituals of the gang bang masquerade\". Bishop said it seems that today the pan is, at best, in danger. Meanwhile, Bishop went on, men who used to make mas are now hustling a, \"CECEP wuk,\" what with so many bands opting to import parts of and in some cases even entire costumes from China and India. Bishop said typically a policy is a principle or a role, which guides decisions with the intention of achieveing rational outcomes. She said policy, however, does not describe what is actually done, but simply provides a sort of mapped out method on how one can proceed. \"Policy deals with the whats and the whys and the hows we do it, but not with the doing itself. Now this is very inelegant language, but I really want to make myself clear. A policy may be described as being a statement of intent and it may arise out of or be applied to individuals, organisations or institutions. \"For example if under a policy about music now for Carnival and we wanted to understand that Carnival is to make money. We have to have plenty people. We have to have a big truck with a lot of loud sound systems on it, a little pan rack would not work. The policy would give rise to the big truck and against the small pan rack. On the other hand as we pursue the big truck we have to remember that the EMA (Environmental Management Agancy) has policies as well regarding the levels of noise. So Carnival music like everything else involves a contest for space,\" Bishop said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/resisting-the-part-time-lovers/article_f2c39f73-778d-5324-a389-740302d6847a.html", "TITLE": " Resisting the part-time lovers ", "DATE": "Sep 7, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " Without the massive contribution of the performing arts, the celebrations for the 50th anniversary of Independence would have been considerably lacking. This is ironic because the current Government's attitude to the performing arts is as patronising and as policy-less as that of its predecessors. I sat on the pavement's edge on Tragarete Road on Independence morning 2012, soaking in ordinary Trinbago at its best, meeting and making good company within a living embodiment of 3Canal's Morning Neighbour, in the warm embrace of Invaders' breakfast sale and later at the first of the Playboyz' entertainment spectaculars. I reflected again on the congenital inability of our \"part time lovers\" of popular culturesincerely to appreciate the richness of what we have, whatever cunning words fall from their spin-laden lips. It has taken me a week to digest the brilliance of the experience. The second of Playboyz productions was a street show with five stages stretching from Cipriani Boulevard to French Street, proving that a small yard could produce a big show. The leadership of Brian Kuei Tung was formidable. His project took a cultural presentation to the proverbial different level. The next day, I read the republication of what Derek Walcott wrote in the Independence supplement of the Sunday Guardian of August 26, 1962, entitled \"The Prospects Of A National Theatre\". Although describing himself \"as a St Lucian writer\", Walcott is positive in his assessment of the cultural richness of Trinidad. \"This is a nation which celebrates with more artistic expression on a popular level than probably anywhere else in the world\". Although Walcott made this assessment 50 years ago, I submit that his summation has remained unwaveringly true of us to this day. It can hardly be contradicted that we lived every word of it during August 2012. Even the military parade on Independence morning is a popular artistic expression. Once the services involved in the parade leave the jacketed and culturally tied confines of the official parade ground, their demeanour changes and there is a lilt in the step of the march past; and so it should be since the march music is calypso/soca. There are sometimes sneering references to indigenous popular culture. These may be provoked by the more extreme manifestations of \"ben' over and wine \", what the Bajan's call \"wukking up\". Discerning commentators however understand the role of popular culture in our society. In his assessment of 50 years ago Walcott also wrote this of Trinidad and Tobago: \"It is a nation of any number of popular poets, the only nation which has a spontaneous national festival of language and music, the only nation which is not faking its ballad tradition, its freedom of artistic and popular satire. The only nation with so much exuberant genius within the archipelago, and the only nation that has done nothing for the arts because the arts are too available.\" Other high-powered commentators have analysed the elements of play within our performing arts and have concluded that some of our play is fundamentally serious and constitutes resistance to the authoritarian streaks in the political cultures which seek to dominate us. See Culture in Action-The Trinidad experience edited by Professor MillaCozartRiggio of Trinity College, Connecticut. Fifty years later our genius has lost neither its exuberance nor its resistance. Our performing arts have survived, not all in the same shape or form, but just as vibrant and inventive. If you doubt my assertion that we are still inventive go and hear the National Steel Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Jessel Murray using the G Pan and PHI, these instruments slowly gaining the respect of the pan movement now that they are no longer instruments of political braggadocio and preference. Indoor theatre at all points between Miss Miles and the comedies of Choo Kong and Ragoobarsingh is in bloom. Nevertheless fifty years later we still lack the National Theatre of which Walcott wrote. The Trinidad Theatre Workshop was itself a victim of governmental eviction from Hart Street. I do not know the full story of its relocation to 23 Jerningham Avenue but I have visited the space. The premises are frail, funds are few, but whatever the history the creative spirit lives. Yes, the relevant ministries do help fund the performing arts but it is so ad hoc, so much of a begging job. There are also enlightened and faithful sponsors but not nearly as many as we need. Meanwhile, there on the streets, like many others, I reaffirmed my independence from the grasp of officialdom. God spare life, as they say, I plan to stay out there, sitting on the pavement edge, chipping in the yard and, indoors and out, taking in all the vibrant genius, loving it all the way, eh Black Stalin.This is where a large part of the real Trinbago resides. I am proud and privileged to describe it. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/rhythms-and-drums-in-st-james/article_9f213775-1718-5928-845f-a4e111002b9a.html", "TITLE": " Rhythms and drums in St James ", "DATE": "Mar 16, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "BEATS WITH PASSION: Nyron Greenidge and Jerry Achee are founding members of the Village Drums of Freedom from St James. The group has for the past 42 years produced an annual festival of culture shortly after Carnival. \u2013Photo: Stephen Doobay BEATS WITH PASSION: Nyron Greenidge and Jerry Achee are founding members of the Village Drums of Freedom from St James. The group has for the past 42 years produced an annual festival of culture shortly after Carnival. \u2013Photo: Stephen Doobay For 42 years a group of culture-lovers from St James have been sharing their passion for the drum with the people of the nation through their annual three-day event. The Village Drums of Freedom (VDF) will from today host their post Carnival production, Rhythms and Drums Around the World at the Ellie Mannette Park at the corner of DeFreitas and Alfred Richard Streets, St James. VDF founding member, Nyron Greenidge told the Express that today will feature a video night where clips of past productions will be shown. There will also be videos exploring African cultures, Afro-Trinbagonian culture and documentaries about various facets of the African continent. This event is free to the public as are the others over the weekend. Tomorrow the VDF hosts a Reggae Night show and dance from 10 p.m. that will include live performances by several local reggae singers, including, King David. Several top conscious sound systems such as Lion King, Black Chariot, Solid Rock and DJ Nardel will be among the systems providing music throughout the night. Sunday is the annual Children's Treat where the little ones from the community and environs will be served snacks and be entertained through games and various activities from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. The Culture Fest will follow with performances by several calypsonians including, Valentino, Black Stalin, Blaxx, Gary Cordner, SuperBlue, Lavway and Crazy. Among the steel orchestras appearing are: Phase II Pan Groove, Scrunters Pan Groove, Tripolians and North Stars. The drum ensembles performing are: Block 4, Culture Shop, Northwest, St James Cultural Drummers and the Wassi Dance Company. There will also be a presentation on the International Year for People of African Descent, which is being observed this year. Other performances include moko jumbies and other traditional mas characters. Greenidge said over the years the VDF has received assistance from the Government from time to time in producing the event, but he said it is not sure if the People's Partnership will offer assistance. They continue to do the events of the festival out of pocket and with the assistance of businesses in the St James community as well as people that contribute what they can. Fellow VDF founding member, Jerry Achee added that the festival is a labour of love and a way to encourage the youth to pursue culture rather than crime. The VDF was formed by a group of pupils from the Mucurapo Boys' RC Primary. The school was participating in the Schools Arts Festival of 1969 and had invited pupils to join the dance troupe. Some of the dancers lived in what was known as the Housing Scheme in St James and they were always liming and playing football and cricket. After the arts festival the group continued to perform under the name of Scheme Rangers. With no adult leader the seven youths saw after their own affairs and eventually attracted the attention of several elders in the area and as far away as Carenage that began to assist them by giving them advice. The group became well known and was invited to perform at various concerts and functions such as opening ceremonies of the St James Youth Centre as well as the Carenage and Maraval Community Centres. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/budding-artists-highlighted-at-tun-over-thursday/article_f8736724-3fab-58b7-9aa1-6e9a24a6f841.html", "TITLE": " Budding artists highlighted at Tun Over Thursday ", "DATE": "Mar 14, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "budding local visual artists: blink | bmobile\u0092s Graeme Suite, head of public relations and external affairs and Naresha Ali, manager mobile marketing pose backstage bSquare with the top three in the blink | bmobile Foundation Art Competition as they receive their prizes. budding local visual artists: blink | bmobile\u0092s Graeme Suite, head of public relations and external affairs and Naresha Ali, manager mobile marketing pose backstage bSquare with the top three in the blink | bmobile Foundation Art Competition as they receive their prizes. The second to last day of the 2014 Soca in bSquare entitled Tun Over Thursday brought an onslaught of entertainment to Woodford Square, Port of Spain. blink | bmobile took the opportunity amidst the festivity to award the three winners of its recent art competition. The art competition which was launched by the blink | bmobile Foundation last October, targeted budding local visual artists between the ages of 16 and 21 years and challenged them to use art to interpret the theme Imagine Trinidad and Tobago in order to qualify for top prizes. The top pieces were selected from the pool of submitted entries by a panel of T&Ts artistic authorities and displayed on the blink | bmobile Facebook page. The three winners, Jahmel John, Nandaa Maharajh and Rajesh Harinarine were present at bSquare on Tun Over Thursday to collect their well-earned prizes as well as to enjoy the pulsating performances by soca entertainers Dil-e-Nadan, Kerwin DuBois, Farmer Nappy, Iwer George and The Baron. Among the prizes awarded that day were Samsung Galaxy 3 Tablets, vouchers for art supplies and most notably the opportunity of a lifetime i.e. a five-week mentorship programme with leading internationally-renowned artist Leroy Clarke. John, a student of COSTAAT, is currently majoring in Graphic Design and aspires to do graphics and tattoo art professionally. His art piece represented The future of T&Ti.e. the children of the nation as seen by a child drawing the map of T&T inside of a heart. He shared, Im very thankful to blink | bmobile for this chance to showcase my talent and for this foundation for my future career goals. Maharajh also expressed gratitude for the opportunity presented to her by the network. The 16-year-old Lakshmi Girls pupil depicted the competitions theme by including several national emblems and aspects which she admired. These included the National Anthem which according to her represents our journey as a people. She plans to have her own art exhibitions while simultaneously studying medicine in the near future. Harinarine who is presently pursuing a degree in Civil Engineering at The UWI has aspirations of being an entrepreneur in his field so that he can have time to continue with his passion of art. His piece entitled Mother Trinidaddepicted a female character built out of different local cultural facets such as the pan, Carnival costumes etc. He stated that the competition was a good way to promote local artists and that he was thankful to blink | bmobile for the opportunity. The blink | bmobile Foundation understands the importance of supporting the fine arts sector as it is no longer considered a mere pastime and that there are presently several local and regional nationals who have made profitable careers as painters, sculptors, textile and ceramic artists, etc. According to a representative from blink | bmobile, It was the Foundations pleasure to host this competition as it gave these budding artists a platform to showcase their work and to also propel the progress of their careers. We are pleased to contribute to the progress of T&Ts young bourgeoning visual artists and the development of the local art industry as a whole.
