{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/patronage-backlash/article_11e5f4f2-673c-5b97-b64e-a28e00d7d29c.html", "TITLE": " Patronage backlash ", "DATE": "Jan 4, 2018 ", "CONTENT": " If Finance Minister Colm Imbert is managing the country's \u00adfinances in the same way he managed the allocation of State funds to the Chutney Soca Monarch competition, then we are in more trouble than we think. A more vikey-vie handling of the issue could not be imagined. That being said, in this matter of funding for the Chutney Soca Monarch competition, we find no reason to sympathise with either the Government or the show promoter. The Government has only itself to blame for the loud public criticism\u2014bordering on irrationality, in some cases\u2014over its cut in funding for the competition. Like every government before it, the Keith Rowley administration seems to have zero interest in implementing the long-promised culture policy so necessary for setting the basis for a transparent and accountable framework for State funding for culture and arts initiatives. As with all other governments, it seems unwilling to surrender the power of political patronage that it enjoys in controlling the State purse. As long as governments prioritise politics over economics and national development, they would just have to take the political fallout that comes with such control. While the predecessor People's Partnership government had enough money to throw around and keep everyone happy, this PNM Government does not and must therefore expect to be the butt of widespread complaint as it divvies up smaller pieces of a shrinking pie among the large number of interests that have come to depend on State patronage. We have no hesitation in saying major profit-making events like the Chutney Soca Monarch and Soca Monarch shows should not be funded by the State. These are entrepreneurial initiatives which, according to figures presented by their owners, attract some of the largest crowds of paying customers. In addition to ticket sales, they cash in by selling advertising space, sponsor \u00adassociation, vending franchises and product placement, among other revenue-earning opportunities. There is no way these shows do not make big money. By underwriting the cost of the show to any degree what\u00adsoever, the Government is just helping these business people to fatten their pockets. Entrepreneurs like George Singh and Peter Scoon and, before them, William Munroe and the Martineau brothers, have demonstrated great business acumen in turning popular indigenous culture into entertaining money spinners. As in any other business, they should have the ability to adjust their businesses during times of economic downturn. There is no law that says these shows have to keep getting bigger in order to be better especially when, in the final analysis, it is the people's love for soca and chutney and the competitive nature of the events, that drive crowd attendance. We therefore see no compelling development support rationale for the Government to bankroll these proven events of high market value. Whatever limited State funds exist should be used to support art and culture efforts that are important but not profitable or are in the nursery stage and require support to deliver on future revenue potential. This is why this newspaper has been urging successive \u00adgovernments to establish an independently-managed Art and Culture Fund, operating at arm's length from the government and State agencies. His longtime colleague, Jack Alexis, said, \"I first met Claude Martineau selling calypso records on the streets. That would have been in the early 70s. We remained friends through the years and Ihave been able to follow his path of commitment to the local performing arts.\" The Caribbean Prestige Foundation for the Performing Arts extended condolences to the family. \"We acknowledge the tremendous contribution made by Claude to the entertainment world and his personal empathy so willingly given to many artistes. \"Indeed, his contribution and joint leadership of Spektakula Promotions with his brother were solid moorings that carried the development of calypso, comedy, soca and dance.\" Also sending condolences was the Trinbago Unified Calypsonians' Organisation. \"The executive and members salute the contribution made by Claude Martineau to the calypso artform and the professionalism with which he conducted the business of calypso. TUCO together with other artistes throughout the Caribbean will truly miss this cultural promoter,\" it said. I was able to attend a few nights and was surprised to see G-rated and child-friendly performances that showcased Trinidad's culture and great talent. I believe the Carnival Village was one of the best aspects of the season and I hope it continues every year. However, I suggest the village be marketed more extensively and clearly. Initially we saw in the media that entertainment would be from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. and there would be an entrance fee. When we got to the village there was no fee (much to our delight), but we were informed that the entertainment did not start until 7 p.m. Also, we heard of the Christian performances only on the day they were supposed to be held, Ash Wednesday. I believe this lack of appropriate marketing kept down the patron numbers for the entertainment portion. I suggest that next year a programme of scheduled performances be listed for every night and the programme distributed in the newspapers, online and at the village. Also, many of the booths did not have enough information and detailed history or attendants to explain their content. The best booth belonged to the soca chutney group which had great historical detail, pictures and helpful attendants. Come on, Pan Trinbago and Tourism Development Company, you can do better. On the night patrons were not around for the videos, a few more detailed displays would have been great. Overall, I really appreciate the effort made with the Carnival Villagethe staff and security were great and I hope the village continues to grow every year and becomes a Carnival staple. Singer/Songwriter, Jumaane 'Juby' Cox. Singer/Songwriter, Jumaane 'Juby' Cox says his New Year's resolution is to finally stamp his name as a serious contender in the music and entertainment industry. Though he has flirted with the idea of becoming a full-time entertainer, Cox says it was only this year he made the bold move and decided to embrace his passion and do music full-time. He said, \u201cI know trying to do this profession part-time was not enough. I knew if I wanted to really hone my craft and make the kind of lasting impact, I had to truly give it my all.\u201d Cox has released two new songs for Carnival 2018 titled \u201cI Wanna Know\u201d and \u201cDoh Jumbie Meh\u201d. Produced by Red Chariot and co-mixed by Millbeatz Entertainment, Cox wrote \u201cI Wanna Know\u201d and collaborated with Kernal Roberts to write \u201cDoh Jumbie Meh\u201d. \u201cDoh Jumbie Meh\u201d was produced by Roberts and Aviqwe Kellar. He said, \u201cThis year is not about negativity. I want to instil happiness in others with my music.\u201d The soca industry is a highly competitive field, and more often than not people do not make it. Despite the challenges that comes with pursuing a career in entertainment, Cox says to be great you must seek and surround yourself with greatness. For Cox, he enjoys entertaining others. Whether it be, storytelling, performing, telling jokes or amateur dance moves, Cox sought every opportunity to showcase his talent. Cox has been singing professionally for the past seven years, and to date has been a finalist in Junior Soca Monarch, a NJAC finalist as well as many other corporate competitions. He has also gotten the opportunity to perform at several major stage shows within the region. Cox's passion for music and culture he credits to his father, Denis \u201cLasana\u201d Cox. He said, \u201cIt was his support and encouragement, which bolstered in me a greater appreciation for the arts.\u201d Cox's musical career reflects a vintage vibe mixed in with storytelling. He appeals to real life scenarios when writing music and interacting with peers on a daily basis. Through his ever changing musical offerings, Cox works on his mission of promoting soca and calypso music to various parts of the globe. Some of Cox previous singles include: Visa Face, Inside and My Craving. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ramadhar-no-consensus-on-bowl/article_9eabe80c-279e-5dff-bb94-203d718cdb94.html", "TITLE": " Ramadhar: No consensus on Bowl ", "DATE": "Nov 14, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "\u0091Decision next week\u0092: Larry Howai \u0091Decision next week\u0092: Larry Howai THE Naparima Bowl in San Fernando will not stop hosting cultural activities and there needs to be more discussion on the use of the historic facility as part of the proposed Naparima Medical Academy. This according to leader of the Congress of the People (COP) Prakash Ramadhar,who said there has been no Cabinet consensus on the issue. Speaking at a press conference held at the COP's office in Charlieville, Chaguanas, on Sunday, Ramadhar said, \"Our belief is that every community has a right to decide or to be included in any decision made as to how their community would be impacted by any governmental project, any governmental development or any large developments.\" He said, \"It is our view that there is a need to have consensus as to how the Naparima Bowl would be used in the future. I want to make it abundantly clear that the Cabinet's decision as I understand it has always been and is that the Naparima Bowl is not to be taken away from us but that the medical training will be added on as a facility and dependent of course on the availability of that facility.\" Plans for the Bowl to be used as the Naparima Medical Academy were announced by Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar shortly after the budget presentation. The decision has sparked an uproar from those involved in arts and entertainment, who insist that the facility be retained without any changes. Fazal Karim, Minister of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education, had said, \"I can say categorically from my information that the Bowl is not going to be closed down to make way for the academy. What is going to happen is that we are probably going to use it as co-existent facilities.\" A committee will be set up to finalise the \"dual-purpose use\" of the Bowl, said Karim. He said that the committee will consist of the University of the West Indies, the College of Science, Technology and Applied Arts of Trinidad and Tobago, the South West Regional Health Authority, members of the Naparima Bowl and the Ministry of Arts and Multiculturalism. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/get-ready-for-therapy/article_e1c45174-52bd-524f-8a73-5d62c7633766.html", "TITLE": " Get ready for Therapy ", "DATE": "Nov 29, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "PURSUING HIS DREAM: Hayden Peters aka \u0093Therapy\u0094. PURSUING HIS DREAM: Hayden Peters aka \u0093Therapy\u0094. He says even if his logical mind were to tell him to give up on chasing his musical dream, his heart would never allow it. Hayden Peters, known best as Therapy a Caledonia, Morvant resident continues to follow his heart. Currently, he is doing all thats necessary to promote himself, in the same breath admitting that getting people in Trinidad and Tobago, to pay closer attention and understand what he is about, has been the biggest challenge. In the past few weeks he has been hard at work in the Juelio Nu Generation Studios where a new pre-Carnival release called, Wine on Somebody has been wrapped up and is set for release across the nation. Therapy says the track, which was written by him will be the first of several new tracks he aims at releasing. Studio time is prime time for Therapy. He has been occupying the recording studio a lot in the past few months, explaining that because of that, he has had very little time to make appearances at events. However, all of that will change, he assures, noting that the time has now come for some serious networking and promotion of his music. With a number of singles already created, the young entertainer says he wont be deterred by anything as he pushes forward. In August, the budding artiste worked with two local entertainment professionals who, ironically, carry the names, Wizz Kidd the music producer and Wyzz Kidd the video director. Together, they released a video medley featuring two of Therapys older singles, Million Dollar Wine and Good Every Time. Therapy says he is happy with the progress so far and plans on keeping a steady head, as he journeys onward. Like many budding entertainers on the local circuit, Therapy understands that one must put in the work. I will continue to put my best foot forward and deliver music thats fit for the world to enjoy, he said. Referring to the work of T&T artiste, Bunji Garlin in recent months, in his bid to highlight just how much of an impact the music of our locals can have on the wider world, Therapy said, We must have confidence in our own product before others can. It would be nice to see corporate entities and Government agencies supporting the arts more, he added, noting that many of the youths who come from depressed communities have held fast to culture and sport as a way out of their situations. Like many in the entertainment industry, Therapy hopes that the Government and corporate T&T could see the financial benefits that could be derived if more investment is made in arts and culture. He however says he wont wait for things to happen instead he chooses to chart his own course, no matter how long it may take. With the love for music on his sleeve and a passion to propel, neither stigma nor obstacle will stop this young musical soul. Music is in me and no matter what it takes, I will show the world just how great my music is. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/tobago-fashion-coda-returns/article_a9092a24-bba2-582f-95a7-3a7cf6257ec3.html", "TITLE": " Tobago Fashion Coda returns ", "DATE": "Mar 12, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Partners to Tobago Fashion Coda share a light moment. From left, Camille Parsons, Advanced Dynamics/Carnival TV; Ancil Dennis, THA Division of Community Development and Culture; Don Grant, CEO DG Events; Samdai Rampersad, deputy PS Ministry of Tourism; Rachel Nathaniel, Magdalena Grand Resort. Partners to Tobago Fashion Coda share a light moment. From left, Camille Parsons, Advanced Dynamics/Carnival TV; Ancil Dennis, THA Division of Community Development and Culture; Don Grant, CEO DG Events; Samdai Rampersad, deputy PS Ministry of Tourism; Rachel Nathaniel, Magdalena Grand Resort. The second edition of Tobago Fashion Coda, is set to take the stage on April 24, the Thursday before the first international night of Tobago Jazz. The ultimate experience in fashion, music and food, will be held under the theme, 'Tobago Love'. The question may be asked what is a Coda It is a musical term that signals the passage or movement that brings a piece to its finale or end. And according to events founder and CEO of the event Don Grant, it is the collection of words or music, that you can't quite get out of your head. Grant held a similar event last year, and this year he intends to pump up the volume, with his event once again. The Ministry of Tourism, Tobago House of Assembly and other sponsors and partners, are set to play a major role in the million dollar event. Calypso King of the World the Mighty Sparrow will be the special guest at the event and will belt out popular tunes such as 'Jean and Dinah' and 'Congo Man'. With fashion designers such as Delia Alleyne, Peter Elias, House of Jaipur, Heather Jones, Gregory Mills, Ecliff Elie, Sean Griffith-Perez, Saleem Samuel and Monica Schinkel, just to name a few, are set to bring the catwalk alive, with a fusion of calypso and fashion. Tobago Fashion Coda 2014, for its second season will take place at the Magdalena Resort pool side, and Grant is promising an unforgettable event. \"It will be the ultimate fashion and style showcase, a premium inclusive event, with an extensive bar of premium liquid refreshment,\" Don Grant says. During the official launch of the event at the Magdalena Resort on Tuesday, deputy permanent secretary in the Ministry of Tourism, Samdai Rampersad said, the Ministry is very mindful of the unique attributes of Trinidad and Tobago, and the mix of cultures and creative energies that distinguishes the island from our Caribbean neighbours. \"It is my understanding that our local fashion industry employs more than 11,000 persons either directly or indirectly, and generates in excess of $25 million annually. With the development of Fashion Coda, Tobago is also being positioned as an attractive blend of fashion, entertainment and fashion,\" Rampersad said. While Assistant Secretary in the Division of Community Development and Culture Ancil Dennis said fashion is therefore, \"\u2026one of the crowning achievements of western civilisation\". It is either creative to the point of being an 'art', enabling individuals and cultures to express their inner feelings and personalities. \"Fashion is a way of life. It's an opportunity for us in Tobago to express our unique culture and heritage. And therefore, the Tobago House of Assembly, in the past would have invested significantly in events such as this one in an effort to promote and preserve our unique fashion industry. We continue to collaborate and partner with people like Don Grant who are desirous of contributing to the development of this island's fashion industry,\" Dennis said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/show-us-your-policy-mr-minister/article_cdb2d8b1-4551-56e4-9f36-6d04eb1ec369.html", "TITLE": " Show us your policy, Mr Minister ", "DATE": "Feb 15, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " Yet another Carnival has come without the Government delivering on its promise to introduce a Culture Policy with clear guidelines for the disbursement of funding and grants. In the absence of this policy, the public remains completely in the dark about how the government is deciding on which entities should receive grants, and how much each should get. This is a worrying state of affairs that lends itself to arbitrary decision-making and public distrust in how taxpayers money is spent to support cultural activities, including some of the biggest Carnival competitions. Prime examples are the International Soca Monarch and Chutney Soca Monarch competitions. Saturday nights Chutney Soca Monarch competition received the princely sum of $4.5 million in direct funding from the government of which $2 million went to the first prize. While organisers of the International Soca Monarch competition are still in discussions with the State about funding, experience would suggest that it is likely to receive at least matching funds, if not more. It is impossible to judge the management and viability of these extravaganzas when they are so highly subsidised by the public purse. In continuing to dole out state funds to private entertainment entrepreneurs, both profit-driven and non-profit, the government runs the serious risk of deepening the dependency on state support way beyond what is affordable with ticket sales and corporate sponsorship. While we accept the critical importance of state support for Arts and Culture, such support should not be extended on some open-ended basis without relevance to san acceptable cost/benefit framework. We know that many benefits are intangible, but even those have to be quantified and guided by clear-cut policy. The public purse can only be protected by a transparent process guided by coherent public policy. Without an intelligent and transparent policy framework, the government could become an easy prey to operators for whom state support is a substitute for innovative financing approaches. In such a situation, the State ends up blocking entrepreneurship, supporting the development of monopolies and denying the markets potential for encouraging greater innovation through competition. Although these issues have been with us for a long time, they are getting increasingly difficult to deal with due to State procrastination. The failure to deal with the challenge will lead, inevitably, to a hardening of assumptions and entrenched feelings of entitlement of support from the public purse. Minister of the Arts and Multiculturalism, Dr Lincoln Douglas has raised the issue of sustainability but he, above all, must surely recognise that his ministrys failure to develop a Culture Policy for guiding the disbursement of grants, is counter-productive to the goal. Having condemned the fund disbursement approach of PNM culture minister Joan Yuille-Williams, the Peoples Partnership Government has been committing the same crime of funding myriad entities on a basis that is not transparent to taxpayers and open to charges of bias, political manipulation and nepotism. We cannot continue like this. Every dollar from the public purse must be accounted for. It is time to present that policy, Mr Minister.
